title: Dual-use items and technology: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1334/2000 setting up a Community regime for the control of exports of dual-use items and technology
background: The EU’s 2000 dual-use export control regime, updated in 2009, faced disparities in national licensing practices and evolving security risks, prompting a 2008 Commission proposal to harmonize procedures. Post-Lisbon Treaty institutional changes required parliamentary involvement in trade-related legislation. The Parliament will discuss amendments to streamline export controls for dual-use items under the updated regulatory framework.

stances.stance:
ALDE entirely approves the issue’s modernization of dual-use controls, perfectly aligning with their demand for consolidated rules to eliminate regulatory fragmentation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s security prioritization, affirming stringent thresholds for low-value shipments as critical to preventing misuse of dual-use technologies.  
ALDE strongly advocates for the transparency framework, emphasizing stakeholder inclusion through parliamentary reporting to uphold democratic oversight and human rights safeguards.  
ALDE commends the integration of ex-ante notification systems, reinforcing Member States’ accountability in maintaining robust export control regimes.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s procedural rigor under the Treaty of Lisbon as essential to fulfilling their longstanding commitment to trade-security balance in EU legislation.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to prevent dual-use technology restrictions from obstructing developing countries' access to critical high-performance computing infrastructure.  
GUE_NGL opposes amendments by conservative factions that prioritize arms exporters' interests over democratic scrutiny, as highlighted in the EPP's undermining of parliamentary negotiation positions.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally doubts with the proposal's tolerance for military collaboration frameworks like EU-funded projects involving Israeli aerospace entities linked to wartime casualties in Gaza.  
GUE_NGL condemns the absence of binding mechanisms to prohibit political abuse of export controls in Central/Eastern Europe, demanding Amendment 47's inclusion to protect technological sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL disputes the regulation's compatibility with equitable development principles, citing unresolved contradictions between dual-use policies and EU research program militarization risks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting a resolution on the control of dual-use items, referencing the Commission’s 2008 proposal (COM(2008)0854) and legal frameworks including Article 133 of the EC Treaty, Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and Regulation (EC) No 428/2009, which repealed Regulation (EC) No 1334/2000 effective from 27 August 2009. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the initial text, ensuring alignment with updated procedures under the Treaty of Lisbon (COM(2009)0665). It instructed the Parliament’s President to communicate its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure and incorporating input from the Committee on International Trade (A7‑0028/2011) and the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

title: Agreement between the EU and Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products and fishery products - Greens/ALE, GUE/NGL: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the agreement between the EU and Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products and fishery products
background: The EU and Morocco negotiated reciprocal agricultural and fishery trade measures under existing Euro-Mediterranean agreements, amid UN resolutions on Western Sahara’s decolonization and post-Arab Spring calls for equitable development. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s alignment with international law, economic impacts on regional producers, and human rights considerations.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s explicit exclusion of Western Sahara from the agreement, aligning perfectly with their commitment to upholding international law and the Sahrawi people’s right to self-determination.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on sustainable development and food sovereignty, which directly advances their priority of protecting small-scale producers and ecosystems in both EU and Mediterranean regions.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call for rigorous sustainability impact assessments, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to prevent child labor and water resource exploitation in agricultural supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA approves the demand for separate agreements with Western Sahara’s legitimate representatives, reinforcing their stance against Morocco’s illegal occupation and resource extraction.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their advocacy for gender-equitable trade policies, urging stricter labor rights clauses in future negotiations to address systemic inequalities.

ALDE rejects the issue’s opposition to the EU-Morocco agreement, emphasizing the €100 million annual gain for EU exporters and enhanced market access as critical for economic reciprocity.  
ALDE opposes the exclusion of Western Sahara from trade terms, asserting that integrated regional cooperation aligns with Morocco’s democratic reforms and post-Arab Spring stability.  
ALDE dismisses claims of insufficient labor and environmental safeguards, citing enforceable commitments to ILO conventions and phytosanitary standards within the agreement.  
ALDE criticizes demands for separate Sahrawi representation, arguing this undermines EU-Morocco diplomatic trust and broader development goals in North Africa.  
ALDE fundamentally condemns renegotiation, viewing the agreement as a strategic tool to reduce poverty and strengthen EU influence in the Southern Mediterranean.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the EU-Morocco agreement on agricultural and fishery products, opposing its inclusion of Western Sahara, which is not recognized as part of Morocco under international law, citing the International Court of Justice’s 1975 opinion and UN resolutions affirming Western Sahara’s right to self-determination. It criticized the agreement for undermining sustainable development, food sovereignty, and small-scale producers in both regions, highlighting risks to ecosystems, water resources, and labor rights, particularly noting UNICEF reports that 1.5 million Moroccan children lack access to education and child labor persists. The resolution urged renegotiation to prioritize mutual benefits, regional cooperation, and inclusive stakeholder involvement, emphasizing sustainability impact assessments to avoid social and environmental harm. It condemned Morocco’s illegal occupation of Western Sahara and exploitation of its resources, demanding EU adherence to international law and separate agreements with Western Sahara’s legitimate representatives. The Parliament also rejected the 2011 fisheries protocol extension and broader free trade approaches, advocating instead for policies supporting decent jobs, gender equality, and value-chain development to address economic fragility in Southern Mediterranean and EU regions.

title: Agreement between the EU and Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products and fishery products - report Bové: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products, processed agricultural products, fish and fishery products, the replacement of Protocols 1, 2 and 3 and their Annexes and amendments to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Kingdom of Morocco, of the other part
background: The EU and Morocco, under their 2000 Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and 2008 advanced status partnership, engaged in negotiations on reciprocal agricultural and fishery trade liberalization amid Morocco’s 2011 constitutional reforms and regional Arab Spring developments. The Parliament will discuss approving a new bilateral agreement modifying existing trade protocols for agricultural and fishery products.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally disapproves the agreement for failing to explicitly exclude Western Sahara's territories, directly violating international law on self-determination of occupied peoples.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the trade terms that incentivize export-driven agribusinesses over small farmers, exacerbating social inequality and environmental degradation in both EU and Moroccan regions.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of binding clauses to prevent child labor in agricultural exports, contradicting core commitments to human rights and ethical trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the agreement's legitimacy in negotiating Sahrawi resources, noting its complicity in Morocco's illegal exploitation of occupied Western Sahara's fisheries and farmlands.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to address post-Arab Spring democratic reforms, undermining stated EU goals of promoting political transformation in North Africa.

ALDE strongly approves the enhanced trade reciprocity framework as aligning with their commitment to economic partnership-driven democratization in the Mediterranean region.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing Annex II monitoring mechanisms to verify Morocco's application of ILO conventions on agricultural labor standards.  
ALDE applauds the tariff reduction structure for creating mutual economic benefits while urging quarterly reporting on Saharan product origin certifications.  
ALDE recommends inserting explicit reference to UNSC Resolution 690 in Protocol 2 to confirm trade measures don't prejudice Western Sahara's self-determination process.  
ALDE endorses the quota system design but suggests tripling phytosanitary inspection sampling rates during initial implementation phases.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and Morocco on reciprocal liberalization measures for agricultural products, processed agricultural goods, fish, and fishery products, which replaces Protocols 1, 2, and 3 and their annexes while amending the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement. The resolution, based on draft Council decision 15975/2010 and draft Agreement 15974/2010, endorsed updated trade terms to enhance bilateral relations, following a recommendation from the Committee on International Trade and input from the Committees on Agriculture and Rural Development and Fisheries. It mandated the Parliament’s President to communicate this decision to the EU Council, Commission, member states, and Moroccan authorities, ensuring alignment with the revised provisions.

title: Agreements on trade in bananas: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Geneva Agreement on Trade in Bananas between the European Union and Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru and Venezuela and of an Agreement on Trade in Bananas between the European Union and the United States of America
background: The EU faced prolonged WTO disputes with the US and Latin American countries over preferential banana import terms for African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) states, violating non-discrimination principles. The Parliament will discuss concluding agreements to resolve these disputes through revised tariffs and financial support for ACP exporters.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's balanced approach to trade liberalization while safeguarding vulnerable EU banana producers and ACP economies, aligning with EPP's commitment to equitable global markets.  
EPP proposes enhancing the POSEI financial framework to address tariff reductions below 2006 projections, ensuring compensation reflects actual market impacts on outermost regions like the Canary Islands and Madeira.  
EPP applauds the €190 million BAM programme as critical for maintaining ACP countries' competitiveness, directly advancing EPP's development priorities in EU partner nations.  
EPP emphasizes strict monitoring of Mercosur negotiations to prevent disproportionate concessions that could undermine EU agricultural sectors beyond bananas.  
EPP urges accelerated implementation of environmental safeguards in the agreement to ensure parity between Latin American and EU production standards.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the tariff reduction framework for reinforcing US multinational dominance, which contradicts their mandate to protect small-scale producers and food sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the insufficient BAM financial package, noting its failure to address systemic socioeconomic vulnerabilities in ACP nations reliant on EU market access.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with sustainable production goals, as it lacks binding clauses to promote ecological practices or local economic resilience.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the agreement’s neglect of preference erosion mitigation, which directly undermines ACP countries’ competitive viability against subsidized multinational corporations.  
GREEN_EFA demands radical WTO rule reforms to prioritize equitable trade over corporate profit, aligning with their 2023 manifesto on decolonizing economic structures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised a resolution outlining a three-part agreement to address banana trade disputes and support affected economies, comprising a scheduled reduction of most-favoured nation (MFN) tariffs for banana exporters, a framework for addressing "tropical products" and mitigating "preference erosion" within ongoing WTO negotiations, and a €190 million financial assistance package under the Banana Accompanying Measures (BAM) programme to aid African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) banana-exporting nations in adapting to market changes and enhancing competitiveness. The resolution emphasized balancing trade liberalization with safeguards for vulnerable economies, particularly through tariff adjustments and targeted support to mitigate socioeconomic impacts on ACP countries reliant on preferential access to the EU market.

title: EC-Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement and bilateral trade in textiles: INTERIM REPORT on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking account of the expiry of the bilateral textiles Agreement
background: The EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, emphasizing human rights and market economy principles, coexists with longstanding allegations of forced child labor in Uzbekistan’s state-controlled cotton sector and environmental concerns over Aral Sea depletion. The Parliament will discuss amending the agreement to regulate bilateral textiles trade after prior arrangements expired.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts conditioning textile trade agreements on verifiable eradication of state-coerced child labor, aligning perfectly with their human rights and ethical trade principles.  
GREEN_EFA approves withholding parliamentary consent until Uzbekistan dismantles systemic school closures during harvests and demonstrates transparent age verification in cotton production.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing independent monitoring mechanisms in Article 6 to verify compliance with ILO conventions beyond government-reported data.  
GREEN_EFA applauds linking market access to environmental remediation, particularly demanding measurable progress in restoring the Aral Sea basin through updated irrigation standards.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that any bilateral textile quotas must include blockchain traceability requirements to exclude cotton harvested through forced labor.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on linking trade to human rights but insists on explicit preconditions for agreement ratification, including verified ILO access and eradication of forced child labor.  
GUE_NGL advises amending the protocol to mandate third-party monitoring of cotton supply chains, ensuring EU imports are decoupled from exploitative practices.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions in maintaining trade privileges under GSP+ while state-coerced labor persists, urging suspension of tariff reductions until reforms are independently verified.  
GUE_NGL proposes binding environmental clauses requiring Uzbekistan to adopt sustainable irrigation practices, addressing the Aral Sea crisis through EU-funded technical assistance.  
GUE_NGL stresses the need for punitive measures in Article 4 if Uzbekistan fails to dismantle production quotas incentivizing forced labor, aligning with ILO Convention 182.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding Uzbekistan’s compliance with international human rights and environmental standards, particularly citing systematic forced child labor in cotton harvesting despite government claims that such practices are limited to private farms and not state-sanctioned. It highlighted evidence from independent observers implicating state actors, including police and security forces, in coercing teachers and families to mobilize children for labor, contradicting Uzbekistan’s assertions. The resolution emphasized the need to revise government-set cotton prices and production quotas, which perpetuate resource limitations and incentivize forced labor. It linked fair trade to human rights, urging the EU to ensure Uzbek cotton exports are not underpinned by exploitative practices. Environmental degradation was also addressed, noting that inefficient irrigation and poor standards caused the Aral Sea’s volume to drastically shrink between 1990 and 2008. Parliament called on the EU to leverage the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement—which binds Uzbekistan to democratic principles, human rights, and market economy norms—to demand reforms, enforce anti-forced labor laws, promote sustainable water management, and align trade policies with ethical and environmental benchmarks.

title: EU trade and investment agreement negotiations with the US: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU trade and investment negotiations with the United States of America
background: Ongoing EU-US economic collaboration as major global traders, including the 2013 High Level Working Group's call for a comprehensive agreement to reduce trade barriers and regulatory differences, preceded parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss launching negotiations for a transatlantic trade and investment partnership.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the TTIP's potential to generate €119 billion annual economic gains and strengthen transatlantic leadership in global standard-setting.  
EPP approves the issue's focus on eliminating non-tariff barriers through regulatory alignment in agriculture while proposing reinforced safeguards for geographical indications and the precautionary principle on GMOs.  
EPP endorses maintaining strict exclusion of audiovisual services from negotiations to protect European cultural identity under UNESCO conventions.  
EPP emphasizes the strategic imperative to accelerate regulatory cooperation frameworks for future legislation, aligning with transatlantic parliamentary dialogue mechanisms.  
EPP highlights the need to exclude defense procurement from the agreement to preserve EU industrial autonomy, converting concerns into procedural enhancement opportunities.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to mandate full public disclosure of TTIP negotiation texts  
GREEN_EFA rejects the investor-state dispute mechanisms that enable corporate challenges to democratic policymaking  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposed regulatory convergence on agriculture as incompatible with EU GMO bans and precautionary principles  
GREEN_EFA declares the issue's growth projections irreconcilable with risks to public services and environmental standards  
GREEN_EFA demands binding clauses prohibiting chlorine-washed meat and hormone-treated beef imports as non-negotiable red lines

resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic and economic significance of deepening EU-US trade relations through a comprehensive Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), emphasizing the potential for annual economic gains of EUR 119.2 billion for the EU and EUR 94.9 billion for the US, alongside a projected 28% increase in EU exports to the US. Highlighting the existing integration of markets, with daily bilateral trade of nearly EUR 2 billion and total investments exceeding EUR 2.394 trillion in 2011, the resolution stressed the need to address non-tariff barriers (NTBs), such as divergent regulatory standards and customs procedures, to unlock further growth, job creation, and competitiveness. It endorsed the High Level Working Group’s recommendations to enhance market access for goods, services, and public procurement, promote regulatory convergence in sectors like agriculture (noting sensitivities on GMOs, cloning, and the EU’s precautionary principle), financial services (emphasizing equivalence and minimizing extraterritoriality), and transport (addressing air and maritime restrictions). The resolution called for strong intellectual property protections, including geographical indications, and safeguards for EU cultural and audiovisual services, while ensuring alignment with labor and environmental standards, ILO principles, and data privacy rights under EU law. It urged transparency and stakeholder engagement throughout negotiations, prioritizing high-quality outcomes over speed, and affirmed Parliament’s role in scrutinizing the agreement and granting final consent under EU treaties.

title: EU trade negotiations with Japan: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU trade negotiations with Japan
background: The EU and Japan conducted economic assessments, summits, and public consultations (2009-2011) identifying regulatory trade barriers and mutual interest in closer integration. The Parliament will discuss initiating formal negotiations for a comprehensive EU-Japan trade agreement addressing tariff elimination and non-tariff barriers to deepen bilateral economic cooperation.

stances.stance:
SD strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on dismantling Japan’s non-tariff barriers, particularly in the automotive sector through UN convention adherence, tax benefit parity, and workshop access reforms.  
SD strongly approves requiring Japan to open its public procurement markets as essential for balanced economic integration, aligning with their commitment to reciprocal trade fairness.  
SD strongly endorses Parliament’s formal involvement in defining the negotiation mandate to ensure democratic oversight, reflecting treaty obligations and strategic prioritization of market access reforms.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with their economic priorities, noting Japan’s role as a strategic partner with complementary industrial bases and shared challenges like sustainable growth.  
SD proposes a September timeline for finalizing Parliament’s guidelines to strengthen the mandate’s clarity without opposing the agreement’s strategic value.

ECR opposes fundamentally the issue's requirement for parliamentary pre-approval of negotiation mandates as incompatible with efficient trade diplomacy.  
ECR rejects the issue's micromanagement of technical regulatory barriers like vehicle standards, which conflicts with their stance on expert-led negotiation processes.  
The proposal completely condemns with ECR's principle that elected officials should set strategic goals while delegating technical details to specialists.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address the operational impracticality of parliamentary involvement in granular issues like UNECE emissions compliance frameworks.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of ECR's trade policy by prioritizing procedural oversight over rapid market access achievements through Commission-led talks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of Japan addressing regulatory barriers to trade as a precondition for launching negotiations on an EU-Japan trade agreement, emphasizing the need to foster closer economic integration between the two partners. It highlighted the commitment from the 20th EU-Japan Summit in May 2011 to initiate discussions defining the scope and ambition of potential negotiations, supported by assessments from the Scoping Group and prior consultations, including a 2009 Copenhagen Economics report and a 2011 Commission public consultation. The resolution stressed that the Council should not authorize negotiations until Parliament formally stated its position on the proposed mandate, based on a report by the responsible committee, ensuring alignment with strategic priorities and addressing trade barriers effectively.

title: Exclusion of certain countries from trade preferences: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Annex I to Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 as regards the exclusion of a number of countries from the list of regions or states which have concluded negotiations
background: The EU historically granted unilateral trade preferences to ACP countries under WTO waivers, replaced by interim Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) in 2007. A temporary Market Access Regulation maintained preferences for countries that initialled EPAs but delayed ratification, prompting a Commission proposal to end this arrangement. The Parliament will discuss amending trade preferences for non-ratifying ACP states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on institutional transparency and procedural rigor, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable trade frameworks that prioritize developmental outcomes.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 3 to mandate periodic assessments of trade exclusion impacts on poverty reduction, ensuring alignment with the EU’s development cooperation principles.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s call for parliamentary re-engagement, which effectively advances their priority of safeguarding democratic oversight in trade policy decisions.  
GREEN_EFA approves the rejection of coercive trade tactics, urging stricter safeguards to protect regional integration projects in Africa from destabilizing market access restrictions.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need to condition any exclusion measures on verifiable progress toward Sustainable Development Goals, reinforcing the issue’s developmental coherence.

ECR absolutely disputes the exclusion framework as coercive trade conditionality that penalizes developing nations' policy autonomy.  
ECR rejects the issue's linkage of market access to EPA compliance, deeming it incompatible with their principles of voluntary partnership and differentiated development paths.  
ECR condemns the punitive withdrawal mechanism for non-signatory states, arguing it violates their core doctrine of trade sovereignty and equitable North-South relations.  
ECR disputes the fairness rationale, asserting the proposal institutionalizes asymmetry by leveraging EU market power against weaker economies.  
ECR highlights contradictions with subsidiarity principles, noting the issue centralizes trade policy decisions contrary to their advocacy for national flexibility.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0598) concerning the common commercial policy under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with procedural and legal frameworks, including Article 294(2) and Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure. It endorsed the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0207/2012) and considered the Committee on Development’s opinion, formally adopting its first-reading stance while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts. The resolution underscored the need to uphold institutional cooperation by instructing its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and adherence to legislative processes governing EU trade policy.

title: Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, Australia, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Mexico, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland and the USA: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, Australia, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the United Mexican States, the Kingdom of Morocco, New Zealand, the Republic of Singapore, the Swiss Confederation and the United States of America
background: The EU and 11 trading partners negotiated ACTA to strengthen intellectual property enforcement amid rising counterfeit trade and online piracy. Confidential negotiations and public concerns over civil liberties prompted a European Commission request for a European Court of Justice compatibility review. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s ratification, addressing intellectual property standards, digital enforcement measures, and international trade cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP totally rejects with the issue's rejection of ACTA, emphasizing its necessity to safeguard intellectual property rights and combat €150 billion in annual counterfeit-related losses.  
EPP rejects the premature vote against ACTA, asserting that dismissing it without the European Court of Justice's legal opinion undermines procedural rigor and fails to address patent safety and job protection.  
EPP opposes the issue's oversight of ACTA's alignment with existing EU IP laws, arguing it weakens Europe's ability to demand anti-counterfeiting measures from non-participating nations like China.  
 While most EPP members opposed the issue, internal dissent emerged regarding digital freedoms, with figures like Paweł Zalewski citing imbalances between creator rights and internet user protections.  
EPP highlights the issue's failure to acknowledge ACTA's role in preventing counterfeit medicines and dangerous goods, directly contradicting their consumer safety priorities.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the agreement's failure to safeguard digital freedoms, directly conflicting with their mandate to protect freedom of expression and privacy as outlined in the issue’s Article 4.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the enforcement model privatizing internet oversight, inconsistent with their principle against corporate surveillance regimes cited in the issue’s "free and open internet" clause.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion of developing economies in standard-setting, contradicting their advocacy for equitable global health access referenced in the issue’s OECD counterfeiting data context.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the agreement’s legal ambiguity on generics, which the issue identifies as irreconcilable with EU public health priorities under intellectual property laws.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the opaque negotiation process, aligning with the issue’s demand for transparent impact assessments to prevent undemocratic policymaking.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) with non-EU countries, declining consent for its conclusion due to concerns over insufficient safeguards for fundamental rights, including freedom of expression and privacy, and potential conflicts with EU intellectual property (IP) laws. It emphasized that existing EU legislation on copyright in the information society is already advanced and aligned with international standards, while noting the economic significance of IP protection, citing OECD estimates of €150 billion annual losses from global counterfeiting and piracy. The resolution highlighted a rise in customs seizures of suspected IP-infringing goods from 43,500 cases in 2009 to nearly 80,000 in 2010 but acknowledged gaps in data on IP violations. It stressed the need for balanced measures that protect IP rights without undermining a free and open internet, asserting that property rights and information freedom are compatible both online and offline. The Parliament called for transparent, independent impact assessments of future legislative proposals and instructed its leadership to notify the Council and relevant international partners of its rejection of the agreement.

title: Application and enforcement of international trade rules: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the exercise of the Union's rights for the application and enforcement of international trade rules
background: The European Union's post-Lisbon Treaty common commercial policy framework required updated mechanisms to address enforcement delays in resolving trade disputes under WTO rules and bilateral agreements, amid increasing global trade tensions. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to strengthen EU capacity for implementing retaliatory trade actions against rule violations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the inclusion of services in trade retaliation measures, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to a dynamic and enforceable Common Commercial Policy that counters asymmetric practices.  
EPP approves the shift to delegated acts for swift enforcement, effectively advancing EPP's priority of strategic autonomy and deterrence against systemic trade violations.  
EPP proposes extending the regulation’s scope to intellectual property rights in future revisions to address evolving trade challenges while maintaining the current text’s balance.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of parliamentary oversight at all procedural stages, reinforcing EPP’s principle of transparency and democratic legitimacy in trade governance.  
EPP highlights the urgency of robust anti-circumvention tools, particularly against non-tariff barriers like Russia’s abusive sanitary measures, to safeguard EU agricultural interests.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on retaliatory trade instruments as entirely conflicting with their opposition to neoliberal globalization frameworks.  
GUE_NGL opposes the premise of EU exclusive trade competence under Article 207, citing its historical use to prioritize powerful states' interests over weaker member economies.  
GUE_NGL demands deletion of provisions equating reciprocity with market access parity, which institutionalize competition harming workers and developing nations.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address systemic trade deregulation causes, proposing binding social/environmental clauses instead of defensive measures.  
GUE_NGL requires amendment of Article 4 to prohibit trade agreements exacerbating intra-EU inequalities, particularly for Southern and Eastern member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen the European Union’s Common Commercial Policy by endorsing the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0773) to streamline trade defense instruments and enhance transparency in trade negotiations. The resolution emphasized aligning trade measures with EU values, including sustainable development, human rights, and environmental protection, while ensuring robust enforcement of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy regulations. It called for greater parliamentary oversight in trade agreements to safeguard democratic accountability and urged the Commission to prioritize reciprocity in market access, particularly addressing non-tariff barriers and unfair trade practices. The resolution also stressed the importance of supporting SMEs through simplified procedures and improved access to global markets, alongside reinforcing safeguards for sensitive EU industries. By invoking Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it underscored the legal basis for EU competence in trade policy and affirmed the Parliament’s role in shaping legislation to ensure equitable and rules-based international trade.

title: Autonomous tariff quota for imports of high-quality beef: REPORTon the proposal for aregulationof the European Parliament and of the Councilamending Council Regulation (EC) No 617/2009 opening an autonomous tariff quota for imports of high-quality beef
background: A 1999 WTO ruling against the EU's hormone-treated beef ban prompted prolonged U.S. and Canadian sanctions, resolved through 2009 and 2011 agreements establishing tariff-rate quotas for hormone-free beef. The Parliament will discuss amending EU regulations to implement expanded autonomous tariff quotas for high-quality beef imports under these agreements.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s alignment with WTO principles and its role in resolving longstanding EU-US trade disputes, advancing ALDE’s commitment to effective multilateralism and trans-Atlantic economic integration.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on reciprocity in urging the removal of disproportionate US restrictions on EU beef, reflecting their manifesto priorities for fair global trade frameworks.  
ALDE proposes enhancing anti-protectionist safeguards in future negotiations to prevent retaliatory measures like “Buy European” clauses, ensuring the issue’s focus remains outward-looking and globally competitive.  
ALDE endorses the call for accelerated EU-US free trade negotiations, recognizing the issue’s potential to drive job creation and shared growth through integrated market strategies.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for sustained institutional cooperation to uphold mutual trust in trade relations, aligning with their vision of a rules-based international order.

SD fully sanctions the issue’s alignment with EU food safety standards, perfectly upholding the ban on hormone-treated beef while resolving transatlantic trade disputes.  
SD perfectly aligns with the agreement’s dual benefit of protecting European consumers and restoring equitable market access for EU exporters affected by retaliatory tariffs.  
SD fully supports leveraging the Lisbon Treaty’s procedural framework to reinforce Parliament’s role in trade governance, enhancing institutional credibility in WTO dispute issue.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s strategic value in safeguarding agricultural producers through tariff quota adjustments that balance import flexibility with domestic industry stability.  
SD applauds the enforceable safeguards ensuring automatic quota suspension if third countries deviate from commitments, aligning perfectly with SD’s prioritization of accountability in trade agreements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 trade proposal (COM(2011)0384), informed by the Committee on International Trade’s report and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s opinion (A7-0025/2012). It formally adopted its stance, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending significant amendments or replacements, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legislative procedures while emphasizing procedural accountability and institutional cooperation.

title: Bilateral safeguard clause in the EU-Korea free trade agreement: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the bilateral safeguard clause of the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement
background: The EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement established a bilateral safeguard mechanism, with the Treaty of Lisbon granting the European Parliament co-legislative authority over trade agreements. The Council moved to provisionally apply the FTA. The Parliament will discuss implementing the agreement's safeguard clause under its new institutional role and procedural requirements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the implementation of Parliament's right to initiate safeguard investigations, aligning with their commitment to institutional accountability under the Lisbon Treaty.  
EPP strongly endorses the inclusion of duty drawback provisions in the safeguard clause and urges the Council to expedite approval to ensure balanced market access.  
EPP proposes enhanced monitoring of Korea’s CO2 regulations for vehicles, advocating for Commission-led negotiations to prevent non-tariff barriers to EU automotive exports.  
EPP approves the agreement’s economic scope but suggests evaluating EU-wide safeguard mechanisms to complement regional measures, ensuring alignment with internal market principles.   
EPP applauds the integration of social and environmental standards in trade policy, advancing their 2023 priority of linking competitiveness with sustainable development.

GUE_NGL rejects the safeguard implementation framework for failing to mandate unanimous Council ratification, creating undemocratic enforcement gaps inconsistent with sovereignty principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the origin rules' treatment of duty drawbacks, which neglect trade unions' documented concerns about Asian production chain vulnerabilities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's crisis-era safeguards as structurally inadequate, arguing they prioritize corporate trade flows over worker protections during financial instability.  
GUE_NGL disputes the "serious case" activation thresholds as unenforceably vague, contradicting their demand for quantifiable injury metrics aligned with SME realities.  
GUE_NGL highlights the exclusion of civil society monitoring mechanisms, entirely conflicting with their manifesto commitment to participatory trade governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the Commission’s legislative proposal COM(2010)0049 at first reading, which pertains to trade-related matters under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it seeks to introduce substantial amendments or replace the proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and institutional accountability. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional dialogue and adherence to procedural frameworks outlined in its Rules of Procedure and treaty obligations.

title: Community regime for the control of exports, transfer, brokering and transit of dual-use items: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 428/2009 setting up a Community regime for the control of exports, transfer, brokering and transit of dual-use items
background: The Lisbon Treaty's introduction of codecision powers for Parliament on trade matters and evolving international agreements on dual-use item controls created procedural gaps in updating EU export regulations established in 2009. The Parliament will discuss amending the regulation to align list-adjustment processes with Treaty provisions, ensuring timely compliance with global non-proliferation commitments and trade efficiency.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fundamentally rejects the proposal’s inadequate safeguards against exporting surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes, directly enabling human rights violations like those seen in Iran’s crackdown on dissent.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the Commission’s security industry prioritization as a betrayal of ethical trade principles, fostering tools of repression under the guise of economic competitiveness.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s failure to address documented abuses involving EU-derived dual-use items, such as Nokia Siemens’ role in facilitating state violence against protesters.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s contradiction with EU foreign policy objectives by permitting exports that undermine democratic movements globally.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding amendments to prohibit all dual-use transfers lacking rigorous human rights impact assessments, aligning with cross-party calls for accountability in trade practices.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on transparency in dual-use technology controls, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to preventing human rights abuses through ethical trade practices.  
ALDE applauds the accountability measures for EU-derived repressive technologies, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of safeguarding global democratic freedoms and digital rights.  
ALDE endorses the institutional alignment with Article 207(2), which reinforces their manifesto goals of coherent EU trade policy and proactive human rights protection.  
ALDE proposes amending Annex I to include dynamic updates for emerging surveillance technologies, ensuring the regulation remains responsive to evolving digital threats without opposing its core framework.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of harmonizing export standards across Member States, strongly upholding the issue’s push for a unified approach to prevent misuse of dual-use items.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0704) concerning matters under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which governs the EU’s common commercial policy. It formally adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing procedural adherence by instructing the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacement of the proposal occur. The resolution underscored institutional accountability by mandating that the Parliament’s President communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with legislative processes and transparency in trade-related decision-making.

title: Financial responsibility linked to investor-state dispute settlement tribunals established by international agreements to which the EU is party: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for managing financial responsibility linked to investor-state dispute settlement tribunals established by international agreements to which the European Union is party
background: Following the Lisbon Treaty’s transfer of exclusive competence over foreign direct investment to the EU, inconsistencies emerged between intra-EU member state bilateral investment treaties and EU law. The Parliament will discuss establishing a framework for managing financial liability arising from investor-state dispute mechanisms in EU international agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on parliamentary oversight and institutional cooperation in managing ISDS financial responsibility, aligning with EPP’s commitment to transparent EU trade governance.  
EPP applauds the requirement for Commission re-engagement with Parliament on substantive amendments, which reinforces accountability in trade policy implementation.  
EPP proposes harmonizing investment protection standards across bilateral treaties to eliminate discriminatory treatment between intra-EU and third-country investors, enhancing single market cohesion.  
EPP endorses linking financial responsibility mechanisms to Lisbon Treaty obligations as a critical safeguard against fragmented liability frameworks.  
 While supporting the issue’s core principles, EPP emphasizes the urgency to address legacy BIT inconsistencies through centralized EU-level dispute prevention tools.

GUE_NGL entirely conflicts with the issue's reliance on investor-state dispute mechanisms that prioritize corporate interests over public sovereignty and development rights.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's foundation in the Lisbon Treaty's contested exclusive competence, which they view as undemocratically centralizing power to enforce neoliberal trade architectures.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of democratic scrutiny by legitimizing arbitration systems that bypass national judicial frameworks and enable corporate challenges to public policies.  
GUE_NGL opposes the institutionalization of financial responsibility frameworks that perpetuate asymmetrical protections for multinational corporations against weaker economies.  
This issue contradicts GUE_NGL's demand to reverse EU competence in investment agreements to allow member states sovereign control over economic development strategies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0335) concerning trade-related measures under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance through the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0124/2013). The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are planned, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural adherence. It further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional cooperation and alignment with EU treaty obligations under Article 294(3). The resolution focused on advancing trade policy objectives while upholding parliamentary oversight and interinstitutional dialogue.

title: Financing SME trade and investment: REPORT on financing EU SMEs’ trade and investment: facilitated access to credit in support of internationalisation
background: The EU's SME sector, representing 99% of businesses and two-thirds of private employment, faced post-2008 financial constraints, declining foreign investment outflows, and non-tariff barriers in global markets under the Lisbon Treaty's trade policy framework. The Parliament will discuss enhancing credit access mechanisms to support SME internationalization and competitiveness.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the issue’s focus on comprehensive strategies for SME cross-border expansion, aligning with their priority of simplifying EU market integration.  
EFD advises strengthening Article 4 to mandate EU funding for trade associations establishing regulatory advisory hubs that decode national rule variations.  
EFD proposes amending the COSME program to create sector-specific information centers under industry federations, offering SMEs localized compliance guidance.  
While endorsing digital trade platforms, EFD highlights past inefficiencies in similar tools and urges binding performance benchmarks in the issue’s implementation clause.  
EFD recommends embedding SME representatives in EEAS trade missions to directly inform barrier-issue strategies, enhancing practical relevance.

SD strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on the COSME program, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to alleviating SME financing barriers through guaranteed loan mechanisms and debt financing tools.  
SD approves the focus on unifying fragmented regulatory environments, which directly addresses SD’s priority of reducing bureaucratic hurdles that disproportionately hinder microenterprises from cross-border operations.  
SD highlights the need to expand COSME’s scope to include targeted support for SMEs entering non-EU markets, enhancing the proposed digital platform with region-specific trade compliance guides as a minor enhancement.  
SD applauds the issue’s recognition of venture capital and public-private partnerships as critical tools, mirroring SD’s advocacy for diversified financial instruments to bolster SME innovation and job creation.  
SD proposes strengthening collaboration with national SME associations in Central and Eastern Europe to ensure equitable access to COSME funds, reflecting regional disparities in financial resource availability noted in the debate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the significant decline in EU foreign direct investment outflows, which fell by 30% in 2008, 28% in 2009, and 62% in 2010, alongside challenges faced by SMEs, which constitute 99% of EU enterprises and provide two-thirds of private-sector jobs. It highlighted barriers such as limited access to finance (with nearly a third of SMEs facing loan rejections), regulatory fragmentation, and non-tariff trade barriers (NTBs) hindering internationalization, noting that only 13% of SMEs operate outside the EU. The resolution urged enhanced support for SMEs through measures like the proposed COSME program (€2.5 billion budget for 2014–2020) to improve access to finance, simplified regulatory environments, and a unified digital platform aggregating trade information and support services. It stressed the need for targeted financial instruments, including venture capital and public-private partnerships, and called for stronger enforcement of WTO rules to combat NTBs and unfair practices, including improved anti-dumping measures and intellectual property rights protection. The Parliament emphasized fostering SME integration into global markets via trade agreements, promoting innovation, and leveraging EU industrial policy to maintain competitiveness, while advocating for synergies between the Commission and the European External Action Service to enhance commercial diplomacy.

title: Financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised countries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1934/2006 establishing a financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised and other high-income countries and territories
background: The European Commission’s 2006 regulation established a financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised countries, with subsequent Treaty of Lisbon reforms altering institutional procedures and a 2008 European Court of Justice ruling requiring adjustments. A 2009 mid-term review assessed operational alignment. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the regulation addressing treaty compliance, expanded cooperation scope, and SALW inclusion.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the reinforced parliamentary oversight in Articles 14a-14c but advises amending Annex A to explicitly exclude regimes with documented military aggression from funding eligibility.  
EFD expresses concern over expanding cooperation to 46 additional countries without proportional accountability safeguards, urging amendment of Article 3 to require human rights impact assessments for all beneficiaries.  
EFD partially agrees transparency mechanisms in Article 4 but proposes inserting a recital mandating quarterly public expenditure reports accessible to national parliaments.  
EFD advises reallocating 15% of the instrument's budget to domestic youth employment initiatives in line with austerity principles, modifying Article 9's financial provisions accordingly.  
EFD requests Article 13 revisions to cap administrative costs at 5% of total allocations, citing taxpayer burden concerns raised during economic stagnation.

ALDE strongly endorses the reinforced parliamentary oversight mechanisms in Articles 14a-14c, aligning with Annemie Neyts-Uyttebroeck's emphasis on institutional balance and expanded legislative scrutiny under Lisbon Treaty reforms.  
ALDE approves the issue’s coherence with development policy objectives, particularly Louis Michel’s focus on prioritizing aid to ACP countries impacted by trade shifts, ensuring alignment with sustainable development goals.  
ALDE proposes enhancing transparency by formally integrating NGO participation into the Instrument for Stability’s implementation protocols, reflecting Annemie Neyts-Uyttebroeck’s call for broader civil society engagement in crisis response.  
ALDE applauds the accountability measures in amended Articles 7 and 9 as advancing their manifesto commitment to rigorous budgetary oversight and anti-fraud safeguards.  
ALDE suggests exploring modalities to progressively align European Development Fund management with the EU budget framework, echoing Louis Michel’s advocacy for streamlined financial governance without opposing current provisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal concerning the multiannual financial framework for 2007-2013, affirming compatibility while emphasizing that annual appropriations for 2010-2013 remain subject to the budgetary authority’s decisions during annual budget procedures. It introduced specific amendments to Articles 3, 4, 5, 7, 9, 13, and 14 of the proposal, including revisions to provisions on delegated powers, transparency, and accountability mechanisms, and inserted new Articles 14a-14c to reinforce parliamentary oversight over delegated acts. These amendments aimed to clarify procedures for the adoption, revocation, and objection to delegated acts, ensuring the European Parliament’s role in scrutinizing and challenging such measures. The resolution stressed the need for institutional balance, requiring the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes to the proposal occur, and underscored alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, particularly regarding trade and development policy coherence.

title: Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No …/... of 28.8.2013 establishing Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No .../... of 28 August 2013 establishing Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences (C(2013)05541)
background: The European Commission adopted a delegated regulation in August 2013 adding ten countries to the EU's GSP+ scheme, which grants trade preferences conditional on adherence to international conventions on human rights, labor, and environmental standards. The Parliament will discuss the procedural approach to listing beneficiary countries under the GSP+ framework.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue's rejection of bundled country assessments, aligning with their demand for rigorous human rights scrutiny in trade agreements.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Annex III evaluations by requiring country-specific monitoring mechanisms for high-risk states like Pakistan, ensuring compliance with anti-violence conventions.  
GREEN_EFA approves the call to separate delegated acts, preventing opaque inclusions such as Burma/Myanmar and upholding Parliament’s post-Lisbon oversight role.  
GREEN_EFA urges stricter timelines for Commission compliance reports, addressing concerns about delayed access to critical human rights assessments.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with their manifesto priority to condition trade preferences on verifiable democratic governance reforms.

ECR completely opposes the inclusion of Pakistan in the GSP+ scheme given its documented regression on human rights and labor standards despite previous textile tariff concessions.  
ECR rejects the Commission's bundled country approach as geopolitically incoherent, grouping nations with divergent governance records like Armenia and Pakistan under a single non-negotiable framework.  
This regulation conflicts with ECR's principle of rigorous conditionality by failing to mandate individualized compliance reports for each beneficiary state prior to approval.  
The proposal overlooks critical damage to EU textile producers from previous unilateral concessions to Pakistan that yielded no democratic reforms.  
ECR demands immediate suspension of preferences for countries violating core conventions, citing Ecuador's environmental deregulation and Georgia's union-busting practices as unresolved issues.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Commission’s delegated regulation adding 10 countries (Armenia, Bolivia, Cape Verde, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Georgia, Mongolia, Pakistan, Paraguay, and Peru) to the GSP+ beneficiary list under a single delegated act, arguing that this approach undermined legislative scrutiny by forcing co-legislators to accept or reject all countries collectively rather than assessing each individually. The resolution emphasized that the GSP+ scheme, which grants duty-free access for over 6,000 tariff lines, requires beneficiaries to uphold core international conventions on sustainable development and good governance. Parliament criticized the Commission’s decision to bundle multiple countries into one act, adopted on 28 August 2013 and set to take effect on 1 January 2014, as conflicting with the need for targeted oversight. It called for the Commission to submit separate delegated acts for each applicant country to ensure transparent evaluation and compliance with Regulation (EU) No 978/2012, which allows for individual country assessments. The resolution also instructed the Parliament’s President to block the current regulation and notify relevant institutions, urging the Commission to prioritize accountability in granting trade preferences.

title: Common commercial policy: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending certain regulations relating to the common commercial policy as regards the procedures for the adoption of certain measures
background: The Treaty of Lisbon’s institutional reforms, particularly Articles 290 and 291 TFEU, necessitated updating EU commercial policy regulations to align decision-making procedures with new delegated and implementing act frameworks. The Parliament will discuss amendments to harmonize trade-related legislative instruments with post-Lisbon Treaty governance structures.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly endorses the issue's transparency mandates for non-confidential trade documents, aligning perfectly with their commitment to open policymaking and preempting public distrust as seen in ACTA negotiations.  
ALDE applauds the streamlined anti-dumping timelines in Article 5, recognizing their critical role in protecting EU industries while maintaining rigorous procedural fairness.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Section 4(2) to explicitly require multilingual publication of key measures, ensuring accessibility across member states without delaying implementation.  
ALDE endorses the mandatory parliamentary resubmission clause as vital for institutional balance, effectively advancing their priority of legislative oversight in trade agreements.  
ALDE commends the rapporteur’s handling of delegated act provisions, which uphold parliamentary prerogatives under Lisbon Treaty reforms central to their constitutional agenda.

SD totally promotes the issue’s strict adherence to the Lisbon Treaty’s delegation framework, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to legislative sovereignty and institutional parity in EU trade policymaking.  
SD perfectly aligns with the emphasis on retaining parliamentary oversight via delegated acts, ensuring no dilution of democratic control over commercial policy as mandated by Article 207 TFEU.  
SD applauds the issue’s exclusion of Member State veto powers in implementing acts, effectively advancing SD’s priority of safeguarding exclusive EU competence against fragmented national interventions.  
SD totally promotes the codification of transparency safeguards, which align with SD’s transparency objectives by requiring Commission accountability for substantive amendments to legislative proposals.  
SD highlights the issue’s systemic clarity as critical to preventing regulatory missteps like ACTA, reinforcing SD’s institutional trust-building agenda in post-Lisbon trade governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0082) concerning the common commercial policy under Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0028/2012). It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments or replacement, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural adherence under the ordinary legislative procedure (Article 294). The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional accountability and alignment with EU treaty frameworks.

title: Emergency autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council introducing emergency autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan
background: In July 2010, catastrophic floods devastated Pakistan, prompting EU humanitarian aid. The European Council subsequently mandated the Commission to propose emergency trade measures requiring WTO non-discrimination rule exemptions. The Parliament will discuss introducing temporary tariff suspensions to support Pakistan's economic recovery while addressing compatibility with international trade obligations.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on legislative transparency and institutional coordination, aligning with their commitment to accountable EU trade policy.  
GREEN_EFA approves the focus on Pakistan's textile exports as strategically vital for post-flood economic recovery, consistent with their development justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 4 to extend the preference duration beyond one year, ensuring sustained support matches reconstruction timelines.  
GREEN_EFA recommends simplifying quarterly reporting requirements to reduce bureaucratic burdens while maintaining oversight efficacy.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to parallel this measure with WTO governance reforms, as noted in the debate, to address systemic trade inequities.

GUE/NGL totally disputes the proposal as it sacrifices Bangladesh's hard-earned GSP+ status for Pakistan's benefit, contradicting their commitment to fair labor and environmental standards.  
GUE/NGL rejects using flood relief as pretext for trade concessions favoring EU importers, highlighting the hypocrisy of prioritizing commercial interests over genuine reconstruction aid.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to protect EU textile workers, particularly in crisis-hit regions like Portugal, where unemployment would worsen under increased import competition.  
GUE/NGL opposes undermining UN/ILO convention-based trade preferences, arguing this sets dangerous precedents incompatible with their principles of equitable international cooperation.  
GUE/NGL demands immediate termination of WTO-centric approaches, insisting direct aid mechanisms align better with their stance against neoliberal trade exploitation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s proposal (COM(2010)0552) concerning international trade matters, adopting its stance at first reading under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) Articles 207(2) and 294. It emphasized procedural adherence under TFEU Article 294(3) and Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure, incorporating input from the Committee on International Trade (report A7-0069/2011) and the Committee on Foreign Affairs. The resolution mandates the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are planned, ensuring legislative transparency. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional coordination and compliance with EU legislative processes.

title: Corporate social responsibility in international trade agreements: REPORT on corporate social responsibility in international trade agreements
background: The EU's treaty commitments to sustainable development, alongside international CSR frameworks (OECD, ILO, UN) and existing trade policies like the Generalized System of Preferences, formed the context for addressing corporate accountability in global trade relations. The Parliament will discuss integrating corporate social responsibility principles into EU international trade agreements to address social, environmental, and human rights impacts.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly approves the mandatory integration of CSR clauses in trade agreements, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to binding human rights and environmental safeguards over voluntary corporate pledges.  
GREEN_EFA proposes revising the OECD Guidelines to explicitly penalize supply chain violations, enhancing liability for subsidiaries’ environmental harms as urged in the issue’s judicial cooperation provisions.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the sustainability impact assessment framework, which effectively advances their priority of preempting social dumping through transparent, Parliament-led post-implementation reviews.  
GREEN_EFA endorses linking GSP+ benefits to enforceable labor obligations, urging stricter monitoring to align with their manifesto goals of eradicating exploitative labor practices in partner states.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity to replace the Colombia FTA’s “meaningless” human rights clause with binding remediation mechanisms, transforming criticism into a targeted enhancement opportunity.

ECR rejects the issue's framework as incompatible with national sovereignty principles in trade policy.  
ECR firmly opposes binding CSR clauses that impose extraterritorial legal obligations on EU businesses.  
The proposal conflicts with ECR's stance against bureaucratic overreach in corporate governance through mandatory sustainability reporting.  
ECR condemns the judicial cooperation mechanisms as creating activist litigation risks against legitimate commercial operations.  
This issue dangerously subordinates trade competitiveness to unenforceable multilateral standards like the UN Global Compact.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative to integrate corporate social responsibility (CSR) into EU trade and investment policies, emphasizing alignment with international frameworks such as the OECD Guidelines, ILO core labor standards, UN Global Compact, and ISO 26000. It called for binding CSR clauses in all EU trade agreements, including revised OECD Guidelines on supply chain liability, and urged the incorporation of CSR principles into the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP/GSP+), requiring compliance with human rights, labor, and environmental obligations by corporations operating in beneficiary countries. The resolution advocated for sustainability impact assessments (SIA) to evaluate economic, social, and environmental effects of trade agreements, with post-implementation reviews and transparency for Parliament. It proposed establishing joint parliamentary monitoring committees for each trade agreement to oversee CSR compliance and address violations, alongside judicial cooperation mechanisms to hold multinational corporations accountable for environmental or human rights abuses by subsidiaries. The Parliament stressed the need to combat social and environmental dumping, promote transparency through annual corporate reports on social and environmental impacts, and integrate CSR into multilateral forums like the WTO, including a dedicated Trade and Decent Work Committee. It highlighted CSR’s role in fostering fair competition, protecting workers’ rights, and advancing sustainable development, while underscoring that CSR should complement—not replace—legal obligations, urging support for SMEs to adopt CSR without undue burden. The resolution also linked CSR to the EU’s post-Lisbon Treaty competences, emphasizing coherence between trade policies and EU objectives under Article 207 TFEU, and endorsed the UN’s "Protect, Respect, Remedy" framework to operationalize human rights due diligence for businesses.

title: Free trade agreement between the EU and the Republic on Korea: RECOMMENDATION on the draft  Council decision on the conclusion of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part
background: The EU and South Korea negotiated a comprehensive free trade agreement under the EU’s Global Europe strategy, following stalled WTO Doha Round talks and increasing bilateral trade dynamics. The Treaty of Lisbon expanded the European Parliament’s role in trade policy approval. The Parliament will discuss ratifying the agreement to liberalize trade and address regulatory barriers.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the enhanced bilateral safeguard clause as vital protection for European automotive sectors, aligning perfectly with their commitment to defend strategic industries and jobs.  
EPP approves the agreement's sustainable development provisions but proposes stricter monitoring of agricultural production chains to ensure full compliance with EU environmental and consumer standards.  
EPP applauds the projected €2.6 billion annual economic boost for EU exporters, matching their 2023 manifesto goals for growth-oriented trade partnerships.  
EPP endorses the cross-party collaboration that secured industry backing for the agreement, reflecting their proactive approach to reconciling trade liberalization with domestic competitiveness.  
EPP highlights the agreement’s enforceable dispute mechanisms as a model for future accords, consistent with their emphasis on legally binding trade frameworks.

GUE_NGL rejects the Free Trade Agreement for institutionalizing corporate competition frameworks that contradict their principle of equitable international cooperation.  
GUE_NGL opposes the elimination of tariffs as fundamentally inconsistent with protections for small producers and industrial sectors like textiles, which face redundancies.  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of binding ILO labor standards, directly conflicting with their mandate for worker rights advocacy.  
GUE_NGL disputes the growth projections as irreconcilable with environmental sustainability imperatives and climate-driven economic restructuring needs.  
GUE_NGL denounces the asymmetric benefits for transnational corporations over regional economies, violating their anti-neoliberal trade doctrine.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Korea, based on the draft Council decision (08505/2010) and the agreement text (08530/2010). The resolution affirmed the legal basis under Articles 91, 100(2), 167(3), 207, and 218(6) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aligning with recommendations from the Committee on International Trade and incorporating the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (A7-0034/2011). It mandated the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its approval to the Council, Commission, and the governments and parliaments of EU Member States and South Korea, finalizing the procedural endorsement required for the agreement’s implementation.

title: Free trade agreement with India: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of play in the EU-India Free Trade Agreement negotiations
background: Ongoing EU-India Free Trade Agreement negotiations since 2007 aim to deepen economic ties amid India’s growing market and the EU’s status as its largest trading partner and FDI source. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s progress, addressing trade barriers, investment frameworks, and alignment with sustainable development and intellectual property standards.

stances.stance:
ALDE fundamentally supports the issue’s rejection of pharmaceutical protectionism, aligning with their commitment to global health equity and cross-border industrial collaboration in life sciences.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for reciprocal access in automotive and alcohol sectors while upholding strict geographical indication protections and GMO-free agricultural standards.  
ALDE strongly upholds the inclusion of public procurement commitments, recognizing transformative opportunities for EU infrastructure firms in India’s railway modernization projects.  
ALDE fundamentally supports the issue’s sustainable development goals, emphasizing partnership-driven approaches to eradicate child labor through supply chain transparency rather than unilateral criticism.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with ambitious services liberalization objectives, particularly mutual recognition of professional qualifications and transparent public procurement rules to ensure equitable EU market access.

GUE/NGL rejects fundamentally the proposed FTA's intellectual property clauses that threaten India's generic medicine production, directly conflicting with their commitment to global health equity.  
GUE/NGL opposes the services liberalization framework for enabling corporate takeover of public procurement systems, undermining Article 12's purported safeguards for public services.  
GUE/NGL condemns the proposed Mode 4 labor mobility provisions as insufficiently addressing worker protections, failing to mandate ILO core conventions in migration chapters.  
GUE/NGL rejects the neoliberal rationale of the agreement entirely, which João Ferreira identifies as exacerbating asymmetries between EU powers and developing economies through deregulation.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's failure to prohibit investor-state dispute mechanisms that Helmut Scholz warns could prioritize corporate rights over environmental/climate obligations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of a balanced EU-India Free Trade Agreement (FTA) compatible with WTO rules, emphasizing its complementarity with a successful Doha Development Agenda. It highlighted trade dynamics, noting the EU accounted for 27% of India’s FDI in 2009 (down from 37% in 2007) and bilateral trade growth from €67.8 billion in 2010, projected to reach €160.6 billion by 2015. Tariff disparities were stressed, with India’s average tariffs at 10.1% for non-agricultural goods and 31.8% for agriculture, compared to the EU’s 4% and 13.5%, respectively. The resolution urged reciprocal duty elimination with asymmetric timelines, addressing non-tariff barriers (NTBs) like technical standards and customs procedures, and incorporating binding dispute mechanisms. It called for ambitious services liberalization, including mutual recognition of professional qualifications and temporary skilled labor mobility (Mode 4), while safeguarding public services regulation. India’s role as a major generic medicine producer was acknowledged, alongside demands to combat counterfeit medicines and protect public health policies in investment chapters.
