The FTA was urged to include sustainable development commitments, ILO labor standards, environmental protections, and safeguards for sensitive sectors. It advocated for opening India’s banking, insurance, and retail sectors, enhancing data protection laws, and ensuring EU firms in Special Economic Zones respect labor rights. The resolution pressed for swift negotiations to conclude a comprehensive agreement by 2011, balancing market access with equitable rules and development priorities.

title: Further macro-financial assistance for Georgia: REPORT on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to Georgia
background: Following Georgia's 2008 conflict with Russia and global financial crisis impacts, the EU pledged post-conflict assistance, including macro-financial support, amid ongoing economic vulnerabilities. The Parliament will discuss additional EU macro-financial assistance to address Georgia's balance-of-payments needs and fiscal stabilization, aligning with broader EU external economic policy objectives.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the allocation of EU funds for Georgia’s economic renewal, aligning with their commitment to sustainable development and ecological transformation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s advancement of Georgia’s European integration but proposes amending the assistance framework to explicitly prioritize renewable energy investments and energy efficiency projects.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the opportunity to strengthen human rights safeguards by conditioning future assistance on thorough investigations into attacks on marginalized communities, such as the LGBTQ+ events of 17 May.  
GREEN_EFA approves the compromise while urging enhanced parliamentary oversight to prevent politically motivated judicial actions, ensuring alignment with EU rule-of-law standards.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that ecological modernization must be integral to Georgia’s economic reforms, reflecting their manifesto priorities for climate-resilient development.

ECR supports the macro-financial assistance as strategically vital for reinforcing Georgia’s European alignment and countering external geopolitical pressures.  
ECR advises conditioning disbursements on transparent judicial reviews of opposition detentions to uphold democratic credibility.  
ECR emphasizes incorporating explicit benchmarks for political pluralism and anti-corruption reforms in monitoring frameworks.  
ECR highlights concerns over recent democratic backsliding but acknowledges Georgia’s progress in economic modernization.  
ECR endorses the aid package while urging enhanced parliamentary oversight to ensure compliance with EU rule-of-law standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the joint text agreed upon by the Conciliation Committee (PE-CONS 00038/2013 – C7-0168/2013), endorsing the legislative act resulting from negotiations between Parliament and the Council. It confirmed the annexed joint statement by both institutions, which outlines interpretations or commitments related to the act’s implementation. The resolution mandated the Parliament’s President and Secretary-General to formally sign the act, in accordance with Article 297(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and to coordinate its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union alongside the joint statement. It further instructed the transmission of the resolution to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, finalizing the legislative process. The decision reflects the culmination of earlier procedural steps, including first and second readings of the Commission’s 2010 proposal and subsequent amendments, without altering the substantive content of the jointly agreed text.

title: Generalised tariff preferences: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 732/2008 applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences for the period from 1 January 2009 to 31 December 2011
background: The EU’s 2008 Generalised Tariff Preferences scheme, due to expire in 2011, required amendment to align with post-Lisbon Treaty decision-making procedures and ensure continuity. The Parliament will discuss regulatory adjustments to maintain trade benefits for developing countries under the Generalised System of Preferences framework.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the extension of the GSP scheme, emphasizing its critical role in reducing global poverty through enhanced market access for developing countries.  
EPP applauds the issue's urgency in maintaining legal continuity, ensuring uninterrupted trade benefits that align with EPP's economic development goals.  
EPP proposes enhancing future tariff preference criteria to exclude high-income oil-exporting nations and non-WTO members, while integrating sustainability metrics to address climate concerns.  
EPP underscores the necessity for the Commission to submit revised proposals promptly, enabling comprehensive parliamentary scrutiny as mandated by the issue.  
EPP affirms that trade preferences must advance both economic development and environmental sustainability, reflecting the EU's dual commitment to growth and climate action.

EFD supports the extension of the generalised tariff preferences as a strategic instrument to incentivise third countries adhering to international commitments on employment and environmental standards.  
EFD advises revising the regulation to mandate periodic updates of access criteria, ensuring responsiveness to current economic and geopolitical challenges.  
EFD underscores the need for future proposals to integrate dynamic review clauses, aligning tariff conditions with evolving EU trade and development priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission's proposal on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences, adopting its position at first reading by endorsing the Commission's original proposal (COM(2010)0142) under the legal framework of Articles 294(2) and 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It urged the Commission to promptly submit a revised proposal for a new Regulation to update the tariff preference system, emphasizing the need for continuity and alignment with evolving trade and development priorities. The resolution stressed that any substantial amendments or replacement of the proposal by the Commission must be referred back to Parliament for further scrutiny. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural transparency and institutional coordination.

title: Macro-financial assistance to the Kyrgyz Republic: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on providing macro-financial assistance to the Kyrgyz Republic
background: Following the 2010 political crisis, interethnic violence, and economic instability, the Kyrgyz Republic pursued constitutional reforms and sought international support. The EU proposed €30 million macro-financial assistance to address fiscal imbalances and promote reforms. The Parliament will discuss the provision of this assistance amid Kyrgyzstan's strategic importance in Central Asia and ongoing stabilization efforts.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the assistance proposal as fundamentally incompatible with their human rights conditionality requirements.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the unconditional aid framework that overlooks systemic torture cases like Askarov's and persecution of Uzbek minorities.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to address Kyrgyz authorities' suppression of independent media and harassment of civil society researchers.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding anti-corruption clauses and judicial reform verification before considering any financial cooperation.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's contradiction with EU values by tolerating documented human rights violations through unmonitored assistance.

ALDE completely advocates the macro-financial assistance as a strategic instrument reinforcing democratic transitions, perfectly aligning with their commitment to incentivize parliamentary governance and WTO integration in Central Asia.  
ALDE emphasizes that the issue's suspension clauses for human rights backsliding directly operationalize their "more for more" doctrine, ensuring conditionality matches reformist aspirations.  
ALDE recognizes the assistance as a geopolitical counterweight to regional powers, advancing EU normative influence through technical cooperation frameworks they prioritize.  
ALDE highlights the Commission's oversight role in structural reforms as critical to addressing their concerns about financial governance and IT system vulnerabilities through predefined safeguards.  
ALDE views the aid package as a template for democratic conditionality, aligning with their vision of EU external action that rewards constitutional progress while maintaining rigorous accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of a position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0925) concerning measures under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, particularly Articles 209 and 294, which govern the establishment of financial and technical cooperation with third countries. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if it intends to introduce substantial amendments or replace the text, ensuring legislative transparency and accountability. It further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence and inter-institutional dialogue. The resolution focused on advancing cooperation frameworks while upholding parliamentary oversight and alignment with EU treaty obligations.

title: Implementation of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the EU-Central America association agreement: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the Agreement establishing an Association between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand, and Central America on the other
background: The EU negotiated trade agreements with Central America, Colombia, and Peru, involving tariff liberalization and provisions to address potential market impacts on EU producers, particularly in agriculture. The Parliament will discuss implementing bilateral safeguard clauses and stabilization mechanisms for bananas under the EU-Central America Association Agreement.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's failure to mandate binding human rights conditionality, contradicting their requirement for prosecuting criminals and ensuring safe return of exiles prior to agreement ratification.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the exclusion of environmental and social standards in safeguard clauses, which renders the regulation ineffective without measurable protections for vulnerable populations.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally challenges with the absence of comprehensive human rights impact assessments, as the issue neglects evaluating local community consequences beyond EU economic interests.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the prioritization of banana tonnage restrictions over systemic justice reforms, directly opposing their demand for substantive pre-ratification human rights verification.  
GREEN_EFA rejects procedural advancement without enforceable mechanisms to monitor corporate exploitation risks, violating their principle of centering affected populations in trade governance.

SD completely upholds the bilateral safeguard mechanisms as they perfectly align with commitments to protect European agricultural sectors and ensure sustainable trade practices.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's prioritization of outermost regions, safeguarding thousands of jobs and recognizing unique agricultural heritage in areas like the Canary Islands.  
SD completely upholds the time-bound stabilization measures, ensuring sufficient adaptation periods for both EU producers and Central American partners to achieve balanced market integration.  
SD perfectly supports the integration of social and environmental standards within the agreement, reinforcing trade as a tool for development and workers' rights advancement.  
SD completely upholds Parliament's oversight role in safeguard activation, ensuring institutional alignment and procedural continuity in implementing trade protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0599) concerning matters under the EU’s common commercial policy, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are intended, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and institutional alignment.

title: Implementation of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the EU-Colombia/Peru trade agreement: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru
background: The EU’s 2012 trade agreements with Colombia, Peru, and Central America included tariff reductions and market access provisions, raising concerns over potential import surges affecting EU agricultural sectors and human rights conditions in partner countries. The Parliament will discuss implementing bilateral safeguards and banana stabilization mechanisms to address transitional market adjustments under the agreements.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely againsts the proposal's failure to mandate a binding human rights roadmap with prosecutions and safe return of exiles before agreement ratification.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the exclusion of enforceable environmental/social standards in banana safeguards, reducing protections to mere tonnage calculations.  
The proposal conflicts with GREEN_EFA's core demand for human rights impact assessments evaluating effects on local populations, not just EU economic interests.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the omission of ongoing local monitoring mechanisms to address Colombia/Peru's documented rights abuses in trade implementation.  
This issue contradicts GREEN_EFA's principle that trade agreements require pre-ratification proof of reduced violence against civil society actors.

ALDE absolutely endorses the safeguard mechanisms as a balanced approach to protect EU producers while maintaining competitive market access.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with provisions granting the Commission necessary flexibility to assess import surges without rigid automatic quotas.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s advancement of parliamentary oversight and civil society consultation as critical to democratic trade governance.  
ALDE emphasizes that avoiding preset import limits prevents trade distortions, aligning with their free-trade principles.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s procedural rigor in upholding Article 207 TFEU, ensuring treaty-compliant implementation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0600) concerning the EU’s common commercial policy under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for alignment with legislative procedures under Article 294(2) TFEU. The resolution underscored the role of the Committee on International Trade, which led the report (A7-0249/2012), and incorporated input from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Parliament urged the Commission to re-engage it if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts to ensure procedural compliance. It further directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing transparency and inter-institutional coordination in trade policy matters.

title: Indication of the country of origin of certain products imported from third countries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the indication of the country of origin of certain products imported from third countries
background: The EU Commission proposed a 2005 regulation aligning with third-country origin-labeling practices absent in EU law, while major trading partners maintained long-standing requirements, creating regulatory asymmetry. The 2009 Lisbon Treaty expanded Parliament’s legislative role. The Parliament will discuss establishing mandatory origin indications for specific imported goods to address regulatory disparities.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s mandate for clear country-of-origin labeling, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to consumer transparency and ethical trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the enforcement mechanisms against misleading origin claims, effectively advancing their priority of corporate accountability in global supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA proposes expanding Article 2 to include additional product categories such as textiles and electronics, enhancing consumer awareness without opposing the core principles.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the reference to European Court of Justice oversight as critical for maintaining uniform enforcement standards across Member States.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need for robust public awareness campaigns to complement labeling requirements, ensuring consumers fully utilize origin information.

ECR rejects mandatory country-of-origin labelling as incompatible with globalized supply chains and ECR's deregulatory principles  
ECR opposes increased consumer costs from origin mandates, citing Commissioner-acknowledged price impacts contradicting single market efficiency goals  
ECR fully challenges with geographical discrimination in selective product targeting, violating non-discrimination trade tenets  
ECR endorses voluntary labelling as market-driven solution aligned with consumer choice preferences over bureaucratic intervention  
The proposal overlooks ECR's core objection to EU regulatory expansion, failing Article 3 proportionality tests under Lisbon Treaty frameworks

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal concerning international trade, specifically referencing the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Article 207(2) and 294(3)), the Commission’s 2005 proposal (COM(2005)0661), and the 2009 Communication on the Lisbon Treaty’s implications (COM(2009)0665). It adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit this position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution emphasized alignment with ongoing legislative procedures under the Lisbon Treaty framework but omitted procedural specifics beyond substantive legal and policy references.

title: Motion for a resolution - Regulation applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the regulation applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences
background: The EU’s Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), established in 1971, grants non-reciprocal trade benefits to developing countries. The 2008 regulation governing the scheme was set to expire on 31 December 2011, and the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force in 2009 introduced new legislative procedures requiring Parliament’s co-decision. The Commission initiated preparations for a revised GSP framework under the ordinary legislative procedure. The Parliament will discuss the renewal and potential reform of the GSP to align with post-Lisbon institutional dynamics and evolving development priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue’s failure to mandate strict enforcement of human rights criteria for all GSP+ beneficiaries, totally conflicting with EPP’s demand to include major economies like China, as raised by Thomas Mann regarding systemic rights violations.  
EPP opposes the omission of EU Member State compliance audits with ILO/UN conventions, directly contradicting Fjellner’s emphasis on ethical consistency and credibility in trade conditionality.  
This proposal overlooks critical aspects such as differentiated treatment for least-developed nations, inconsistent with Papastamkos’ call for economic targeting to prevent harming vulnerable economies.  
The issue’s blanket approach to beneficiary assessments conflicts with EPP’s stance on case-specific evaluations, exemplified by Andrikienė’s objection to singling out Colombia despite alleged progress.  
EPP rejects the lack of binding mechanisms for Parliamentary oversight in beneficiary monitoring, opposing Niculescu’s insistence on formal consultation rights during GSP+ applicant reviews.

SD strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on linking GSP+ benefits to strict implementation of human rights and environmental conventions, aligning with their commitment to ethical trade practices.  
SD applauds the call for enhanced transparency and annual compliance reports, which directly advance accountability in trade policy as outlined in their 2023 development agenda.  
SD proposes strengthening civil society involvement in monitoring GSP+ implementation, mirroring mechanisms used in recent trade agreements to ensure grassroots oversight.  
SD endorses the demand for parliamentary inclusion in investigations and beneficiary country evaluations, ensuring democratic scrutiny aligns with their institutional reform priorities.  
SD highlights the need for balanced assessments of compliance to avoid unilateral judgments, suggesting periodic multilateral reviews to maintain objectivity in tariff preference decisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) as a non-reciprocal trade mechanism enabling developed countries to support developing nations by reducing tariffs, fostering sustainable development, and addressing trade imbalances since its inception in 1971. It highlighted the impending expiration of the current GSP regulation on 31 December 2011 and urged the Commission to propose a revised regulation by 1 June 2010 under the ordinary legislative procedure, emphasizing the need to target preferences toward countries most in need based on their economic conditions. The resolution stressed that GSP+ beneficiaries must effectively implement all 27 listed ILO and UN conventions on human rights, labor, and environmental standards, calling for enhanced transparency, regular monitoring, and annual compliance reports to Parliament and the Council. It demanded an impact assessment of the GSP’s effectiveness from 2006 to 2009, focusing on socio-economic indicators and poverty reduction, to inform the revised regulation. Additionally, the Parliament insisted on greater involvement in GSP decision-making processes, including investigations and beneficiary country listings, and required the Commission to evaluate the GSP+ incentive system’s efficacy, propose updates to conventions, and establish mechanisms for temporary withdrawal of preferences in cases of non-compliance.

title: Motions for resolutions - Interim Partnership Agreement between the EC and the Pacific States: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Interim Partnership Agreement between the EC and the Pacific States
background: The European Commission negotiated a 2007 interim EPA with Papua New Guinea and Fiji to maintain WTO-compliant trade preferences after Cotonou Agreement provisions expired, focusing on tuna and sugar exports. The Parliament will discuss the agreement's alignment with development objectives, regional integration prospects, and trade impacts under EU-Pacific relations.

stances.stance:
SD fundamentally agrees the issue's imperative to strengthen regional economic integration in the Pacific through equitable partnership frameworks.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for rigorous monitoring of rules of origin to prevent third-country exploitation while advancing sustainable local industries.  
SD fundamentally agrees the issue’s alignment with international labor standards and sustainable fisheries management as non-negotiable agreement pillars.  
SD perfectly supports immediate Commission reporting mechanisms to verify developmental impacts without compromising EU market integrity.  
SD fundamentally agrees binding safeguards against monopolistic processing practices that undermine both Pacific states’ growth and EU trade fairness.

GUE/NGL firmly doubts the Interim Partnership Agreement for legitimizing Fiji's military dictatorship, directly contradicting their commitment to democratic governance and undermining regional democracy restoration efforts.  
GUE/NGL rejects the bilateral negotiation model as a fragmentation of Pacific regional integration, aligning with ACP states' critiques of EU coercive tactics in EPA negotiations.  
GUE/NGL condemns the agreement's failure to provide meaningful development support, exposing its prioritization of EU trade interests over sustainable growth in Papua New Guinea and Fiji.  
GUE/NGL opposes the Commission's recognition of authoritarian regimes through trade agreements, which violates their principle of conditioning partnerships on human rights and democratic norms.  
GUE/NGL demands immediate suspension of the agreement until Fiji reinstates democratic institutions, citing its incompatibility with EU values and parliamentary issues condemning the 2006 coup.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the escalating threats to media freedom and pluralism within the EU, emphasizing the need to safeguard journalists and independent outlets from political interference, harassment, and economic pressures. It called for stronger enforcement of EU rule-of-law mechanisms to address systemic violations in member states, particularly targeting misuse of state resources to manipulate media. The resolution highlighted the disproportionate concentration of media ownership, urging transparency measures and limits on monopolistic practices. It stressed the importance of protecting journalists’ sources, opposing surveillance without judicial oversight, and ensuring accountability for attacks on press freedom. The Parliament also advocated for increased funding to support investigative journalism and local media, while condemning strategic lawsuits against public participation (SLAPPs) used to silence critics. Additionally, it urged the Commission to propose legislation establishing minimum standards for media independence and pluralism, including safeguards against political bias in public service broadcasting.

title: Report: Iuliu Winkler - Macro-financial assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision providing macro-financial assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina
background: The global financial crisis and regional instability in the Balkans and Caucasus strained economies of European Neighbourhood Policy partners, prompting requests for EU support amid fiscal deficits and balance-of-payments pressures. The Parliament will discuss a proposal to provide exceptional EU macro-financial assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely advocates the immediate provision of macro-financial assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina, perfectly aligning with its strategic commitment to Balkan stability and EU accession processes.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the urgency of bypassing prolonged legislative procedures to address critical balance-of-payments constraints in partner countries like Armenia and Georgia.  
EPP emphasizes that assisting potential EU candidates like Serbia reinforces the Union's geopolitical interests, mirroring its 2023 enlargement policy priorities.  
EPP strongly affirms that this assistance framework exemplifies Europe's solidarity with nations recovering from conflict-induced economic shocks, consistent with its crisis-response principles.  
EPP underscores the necessity of maintaining institutional cooperation through prompt Council-Parliament notifications, ensuring procedural transparency while accelerating vital aid delivery.

GREEN_EFA rejects the exclusionary simplified MFA procedure as fundamentally undermining parliamentary oversight, directly contradicting their mandate for institutional transparency.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the delayed implementation timeline, which exacerbates Georgia’s crisis while EU states fuel regional militarization through arms sales to Russia.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the failure to prevent MFA misuse for military purposes, violating their non-violence principles and enabling Black Sea destabilization.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the hypocrisy of conditioning aid recipients’ military spending while EU members supply advanced weaponry to aggressor states like Russia.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the strategic incoherence of aiding conflict-impacted states without addressing root causes like EU complicity in arms proliferation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Commission proposal (COM(2009)0596) to adapt EU legislation following the accession of new member states, emphasizing the need for legal coherence. It urged the Council to notify Parliament promptly if it intends to deviate from the approved text and to consult Parliament again should the Council propose substantial amendments to the Commission’s original proposal. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment in the legislative process while upholding procedural transparency and institutional cooperation.

title: Report: Miloslav Ransdorf - Macro-financial assistance to Serbia: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision providing macro-financial assistance to Serbia
background: Serbia, a potential EU candidate, faced fiscal deficits and balance-of-payments pressures exacerbated by the 2008 global financial crisis, structural economic challenges from the 1999 NATO conflict, and regional instability. The Parliament will discuss a Council proposal to provide EU macro-financial assistance addressing Serbia’s economic stabilization needs.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely conflicts the macro-financial assistance framework for Serbia, as it replicates exclusionary procedural shortcuts that marginalize parliamentary oversight, directly contradicting their demands for democratic accountability in EU financial mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal’s failure to explicitly prohibit funds from supporting military infrastructure or regional destabilization, a critical omission given ongoing EU member state arms sales to conflict actors like Russia, which exacerbate instability in adjacent regions.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with peace-building principles, noting that financial aid cannot offset the harm caused by EU states’ militarized trade policies in conflict-prone areas like the Balkans.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Commission’s procedural delays and lack of transparency in MFA disbursements, which undermine the credibility of EU assistance programs and their alignment with human rights conditionality.  
GREEN_EFA asserts that the proposal overlooks systemic contradictions in EU policy, where financial aid to crisis-affected states coexists with member state actions that fuel regional arms races and security dilemmas.

SD fully promotes the macro-financial assistance to Serbia, perfectly aligning with their commitment to Balkan stability and EU enlargement through crisis-era solidarity.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of bypassing procedural delays under the Lisbon Treaty to ensure timely aid delivery, reflecting their prioritization of economic rescue over bureaucratic formalities.  
SD applauds the issue’s role in mitigating unemployment and foreign capital deficits, directly advancing their manifesto goals of preventing destabilizing shocks in accession-focused regions.  
SD underscores the assistance as a strategic reinforcement of Serbia’s European integration path, consistent with their advocacy for proactive EU engagement in Southeast Europe.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with their principles of preempting ethnic tensions through economic stabilization, ensuring social cohesion amid recession-driven discontent.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Commission proposal COM(2009)0513, which was based on Article 308 of the EC Treaty, and urged the Council to notify Parliament promptly if it intends to deviate from the approved text or to consult Parliament again should it propose substantial amendments to the Commission’s original proposal. The resolution emphasized adherence to procedural cooperation by instructing the Parliament’s President to communicate its position to the Council and Commission, ensuring alignment in the legislative process while maintaining parliamentary oversight over any significant changes to the proposal.

title: Interim agreement establishing a framework for an EC-Eastern and Southern Africa States Economic Partnership Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Interim Agreement establishing a framework for an Economic Partnership Agreement between Eastern and Southern Africa States, on the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, on the other part
background: The EU and Eastern/Southern African states negotiated an interim Economic Partnership Agreement to replace expiring WTO-incompatible unilateral trade preferences under the Cotonou Agreement, aiming to establish reciprocal trade terms and regional integration frameworks. The Parliament will discuss concluding the agreement establishing asymmetric market access and development cooperation provisions.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly approves the Agreement's framework for WTO-compliant trade integration, aligning with their commitment to predictable market access and global economic participation.  
ECR applauds the focus on strengthening regional African markets as a catalyst for sustainable development, consistent with their advocacy for sovereignty-driven economic partnerships.  
ECR proposes refining provisions on development ownership to explicitly prioritize African-led industrialization strategies while maintaining core Agreement commitments.  
ECR endorses the elimination of unilateral preferences as a necessary step toward balanced trade relations grounded in mutual accountability.  
ECR emphasizes the need for enhanced implementation reviews to ensure benefits materialize equitably across all signatory states.

GUE_NGL rejects the Interim EPA as it entirely doubts with their opposition to neoliberal trade policies that prioritize EU corporate interests over African development.  
GUE_NGL opposes the tariff elimination clauses causing massive revenue losses (€141m Seychelles/€14m Madagascar), directly contradicting their stance against austerity impacts on public health and education.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement’s obstruction of COMESA regional integration, violating their principle of South-South solidarity against EU market fragmentation tactics.  
GUE_NGL denounces the Commission’s coercive negotiation methods as incompatible with their anti-imperialist framework for equitable North-South relations.  
GUE_NGL highlights the exclusion of civil society consultations, opposing top-down trade models that bypass grassroots democratic processes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Eastern and Southern Africa states, specifically Madagascar, Mauritius, the Seychelles, and Zimbabwe, aimed at establishing a framework for enhanced trade and economic cooperation. The resolution, based on the proposal (11699/2012) and legal provisions under Articles 207(4), 209(2), and 218(6) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsed the Agreement to promote regional integration, sustainable development, and mutual economic benefits. It highlighted the role of the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on Development in evaluating the Agreement (A7-0431/2012), emphasizing compliance with EU trade policies and development objectives. The Parliament instructed its President to communicate its approval to the Council, Commission, and relevant national governments and parliaments, finalizing the procedural step for the Agreement’s implementation.

title: International Trade Policy in the context of Climate Change imperatives: REPORT on international trade policy in the context of climate change imperatives
background: The EU's climate commitments under the 2008 Climate Change Package, 2009 Copenhagen Accord, and IPCC findings faced challenges from global trade dynamics, carbon leakage risks, and divergent national climate policies. The Parliament will discuss aligning international trade frameworks with climate objectives to address emissions embedded in cross-border commerce and supply chains.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the integration of climate objectives into trade policies, particularly WTO reforms to align environmental standards with carbon pricing mechanisms, which aligns perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to sustainable economic frameworks.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on corporate social responsibility clauses in trade agreements, as demonstrated by successful implementations with South Korea and Colombia, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of ethical trade practices.  
EPP proposes enhancing inter-policy collaboration to ensure environmental and social frameworks independently meet climate targets, thereby preventing trade policy from being overburdened—a minor refinement to strengthen holistic governance.  
EPP endorses strict human rights and environmental conditionality in trade agreements, including prohibitions on goods linked to forced labor, which matches their manifesto pledge to eliminate unfair competition through traceable production methods.  
EPP urges amending the issue’s critique of the EU’s common agricultural model to explicitly prioritize food security alongside climate goals, ensuring self-sufficiency remains central without opposing sustainability principles.

ECR rejects the issue's exclusive focus on climate mechanisms without binding human rights safeguards in trade agreements.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the omission of religious freedom protections when granting trade advantages to countries like Pakistan.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as enforceable anti-persecution clauses paralleling environmental commitments.  
ECR condemns the failure to mandate child labor prohibitions as rigorously as carbon footprint distinctions in WTO reforms.  
This absolutely againsts with ECR's position that trade must condition market access on verifiable human rights progress.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the inadequacy of the 2009 Copenhagen climate agreement and the EU’s failure to present a unified, ambitious strategy to limit global warming to below 2°C. It reaffirmed the EU’s commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2020 and 80-95% by 2050 (compared to 1990 levels), urging binding international agreements and stronger verification mechanisms. The resolution emphasized integrating climate objectives into trade policies, advocating WTO reforms to align trade rules with environmental goals, including distinguishing products by carbon footprint and production methods (PPMs), and granting precedence to multilateral environmental agreements over trade disputes. It called for carbon pricing mechanisms, such as a minimum carbon price under the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS), and border adjustments to address carbon leakage, while ensuring WTO compliance. The Parliament stressed phasing out fossil fuel subsidies, promoting renewable energy, and enforcing strict sustainability criteria for biofuels, biomass, and timber to prevent deforestation. It highlighted the need to internalize transport-related emissions, including maritime and aviation sectors in the ETS by 2013, and urged technology transfers and financial support for developing countries, including innovative funding like financial transaction taxes. The resolution also demanded trade agreements include enforceable climate chapters, prioritize food security over biofuel production, and address consumption-related emissions, citing figures such as 35% (UK), 45% (France), and 60% (Sweden) of emissions linked to imported goods.

title: Government procurement agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol Amending the Agreement on Government Procurement
background: The WTO’s 1994 Government Procurement Agreement, involving the EU, US, and others, governed transnational procurement. EU procurement policy revisions and multilateral efforts to expand membership, including developing countries, preceded parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss adopting updated international procurement rules under the WTO framework.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely endorses the Protocol's alignment with EU Procurement Directives, reinforcing transparency and securing €30 billion in new market-access opportunities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on electronic procurement systems, enhancing legal certainty and combating corruption through standardized supplier exclusion rules.  
EPP applauds the Protocol’s role in advancing international trade negotiations, reflecting EPP’s commitment to multilateral frameworks and swift WTO agreement ratification.  
EPP emphasizes the Protocol’s strategic value in synchronizing EU internal procurement standards with global practices, ensuring coherence and competitiveness.  
EPP highlights the Protocol’s transitional measures for developing countries as exemplary of EU leadership in fostering inclusive yet rigorous international trade norms.

GUE_NGL conditionally sanctions the Protocol only if Article 2 is amended to explicitly exclude water, healthcare, and education from market competition clauses.  
GUE_NGL requests revisions to Section 4.3 requiring binding social/environmental criteria in procurement contracts to prevent race-to-the-bottom labor practices.  
This completely condemns with GUE_NGL's position that public services must remain state-controlled, failing to address neoliberal erosion of communal infrastructure ownership.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as carve-outs for local employment protections, inconsistent with the party's 2022 manifesto on economic sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL demands Annex B be rewritten to prohibit transnational corporations from bidding on municipal housing/energy contracts without public oversight mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol Amending the Agreement on Government Procurement (07918/2013), endorsing updates to the existing framework for government procurement to enhance transparency, fairness, and competition in public contracting across signatory states. The resolution, based on the Council’s request under Article 207(4) and Article 218(6) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, followed recommendations from the Committee on International Trade and considered the opinion of the Committee on Development (A7-0339/2013). It authorized the finalization of the Protocol, emphasizing alignment with EU trade and development objectives, and directed the Parliament’s President to communicate its approval to the Council, Commission, and member state governments and parliaments to facilitate ratification and implementation.

title: Granting delegated powers for the adoption of certain measures relating to the common commercial policy: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending certain regulations relating to the common commercial policy as regards the granting of delegated powers for the adoption of certain measures
background: The Treaty of Lisbon expanded the European Parliament’s legislative role in trade policy, requiring updates to align existing regulations with post-Lisbon institutional procedures. The Commission proposed amendments to adapt decision-making mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss granting delegated powers to the Commission under the common commercial policy.

stances.stance:
SD strongly upholds the five-year limitation on delegated powers, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to accountable governance through periodic parliamentary oversight.  
SD applauds the issue's procedural alignment with Treaty of Lisbon reforms, effectively advancing SD's priority of institutional parity in trade policy decision-making.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4 to formalize Parliament’s expert participation in preparatory technical meetings, ensuring collaborative implementation of delegated acts.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to maintain EU exclusive competence in trade policy, rejecting fragmented national approaches that weaken global negotiation positions.  
SD urges accelerated Council engagement to finalize this reform, highlighting interinstitutional delays as counterproductive to post-Lisbon legislative coherence.

GUE_NGL partially agrees the delegated powers framework in Article 2 but insists on binding parliamentary veto mechanisms to prevent unchecked Commission authority, as current safeguards fail to address democratic deficit risks.  

GUE_NGL objects to the Council's institutional obstructionism regarding delegated acts, which directly contradicts the treaty principle of parliamentary equality under Article 207 TFEU.  

GUE_NGL requests revisions to impose strict timelines for Commission re-engagement with Parliament, amending Recital 9 to specify 30-day response requirements when legislative amendments exceed original scope.  

GUE_NGL warns that procedural delays caused by Member States' resistance to power-sharing fundamentally undermine the issue's transparency goals, requiring explicit sanctions in Article 4(2) against non-compliant institutions.  

GUE_NGL demands reinforced accountability clauses to align with their anti-technocratic principles, proposing amended wording in Section 3(c) to mandate public hearings before any trade measure adoption.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning the European Union’s common commercial policy, based on the Commission’s initial proposal (COM(2011)0349) and aligned with Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are considered, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. The resolution referenced the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0096/2012) as foundational to its deliberations and instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional coordination and adherence to EU legislative processes.

title: Human rights, social and environmental standards in International Trade agreements: REPORT on human rights and social and environmental standards in international trade agreements
background: The European Union’s trade agreements have increasingly incorporated clauses on human rights, labor, and environmental standards, referencing UN conventions, ILO core norms, and multilateral environmental treaties. The Lisbon Treaty’s emphasis on external action coherence and existing frameworks like the Cotonou Agreement shape this approach. The Parliament will discuss integrating these standards into international trade agreements.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s mandate for legally binding social and environmental clauses in trade agreements, aligning perfectly with their commitment to combat labor exploitation and ecological harm through enforceable frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on corporate accountability via OECD guidelines and binding arbitration, which directly addresses their concerns about transnational corporations’ unchecked environmental and labor abuses.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening human rights clauses in existing FTAs, such as the Colombia agreement, to ensure they transcend formulaic language and deliver tangible protections against rights violations.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the creation of a World Environmental Organization and enhanced ILO authority as critical steps to institutionalize sustainability and labor equity in global trade governance.  
GREEN_EFA urges accelerated implementation of the “carbon inclusion mechanism” and stricter GSP+ conditionality to prevent CO2 leakage and social dumping, reflecting their demand for trade policy that prioritizes planetary boundaries.

ECR rejects the issue's binding environmental clauses as incompatible with national sovereignty principles, particularly opposing EU-level enforcement of ILO standards.  
ECR absolutely doubts the carbon inclusion mechanism, viewing it as regulatory overreach inconsistent with market-driven solutions advocated in their 2023 trade manifesto.  
The proposal’s reliance on UN/WTO oversight conflicts with ECR’s stance against supranational governance structures, disregarding bilateral negotiation priorities.  
ECR condemns the blanket import ban approach for goods linked to modern slavery, arguing it undermines trade autonomy and fails to address root causes through partnership.  
The issue’s mandatory arbitration for corporate accountability overlooks critical aspects of voluntary OECD guideline adherence, a cornerstone of ECR’s trade policy framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative to integrate human rights, labor, and environmental standards into EU trade policy, emphasizing that trade agreements must serve as tools to promote universal values, fair competition, and sustainable development. It called for legally binding social and environmental clauses in all bilateral and multilateral agreements, including bans on child labor—particularly in natural stone extraction—and forced labor, with a certification system to ensure compliance with ILO Convention 182. The resolution stressed the need for reciprocity and differentiated approaches based on partners’ development levels, while opposing social or environmental dumping. It advocated for cooperation between the WTO and UN bodies like the ILO to align trade with human rights, proposing a World Environmental Organization post-climate agreement and a "carbon inclusion mechanism" to address CO2 leakage. The Parliament urged stricter enforcement of human rights clauses, including suspension of trade preferences under the GSP+ system for violations, and demanded EU import bans on goods linked to modern slavery. It highlighted the importance of transparency, civil society involvement, and parliamentary oversight in trade negotiations, aligning with the Lisbon Treaty’s objectives. Additionally, the resolution emphasized support for developing countries through fair Economic Partnership Agreements, sustainable fisheries, and adherence to UN Millennium Goals, while ensuring corporate accountability via OECD guidelines and binding arbitration for disputes. Environmental commitments included promoting green technologies, climate-friendly trade rules, and compliance with multilateral agreements like the Kyoto Protocol. The Parliament also called for regular impact assessments, monitoring of labor rights, and measures to prevent illicit capital flight, underscoring coherence between EU policies and global human rights obligations.

title: Regional Convention on pan-Euro-Mediterranean preferential rules of origin: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the regional Convention on pan-Euro-Mediterranean preferential rules of origin
background: Existing bilateral protocols on rules of origin under the Barcelona Process and Union for the Mediterranean framework, alongside post-2011 Arab Spring calls for enhanced regional economic integration, shaped efforts to streamline Euro-Mediterranean trade. The Parliament will discuss concluding a regional convention harmonizing preferential rules of origin and expanding cumulation across the pan-Euro-Mediterranean area.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the convention’s harmonization of rules of origin as a critical step toward Euro-Mediterranean economic integration, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to reducing trade barriers and fostering regional stability through shared prosperity.  
SD approves the replacement of over 100 bilateral protocols with a unified framework but proposes enhancing dispute settlement mechanisms to ensure equitable enforcement across all signatory states.  
SD endorses the convention’s potential to spur economic growth in developing Mediterranean and Balkan countries, effectively advancing SD’s priority of poverty reduction through trade diversification.  
SD recommends strengthening provisions to exclude goods from occupied territories from preferential treatment, urging an upgrade of the EU-Israel Technical Arrangement to a legally binding agreement as a necessary safeguard.  
SD highlights the need for complementary initiatives to modernize customs cooperation and South-South trade frameworks, ensuring the convention serves as a foundation for deeper political and economic reforms.

GUE_NGL rejects the convention for failing to explicitly exclude goods from illegal Israeli settlements, enabling complicity in occupation and human rights violations  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue as reinforcing EU free-trade dogmas that prioritize multinational corporations over workers' rights and regional equity  
GUE_NGL condemns the lack of binding mechanisms to prevent Israel from exploiting trade preferences for settlement products, violating international law  
GUE_NGL fully doubts with the convention's alignment with unregulated trade zones that historically empower dictatorships and destabilize Mediterranean partners  
GUE_NGL demands immediate closure of all EU market access routes for settlement goods rather than creating new preferential loopholes

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Regional Convention on Pan-Euro-Mediterranean Preferential Rules of Origin, aimed at harmonizing rules of origin across Euro-Mediterranean countries to facilitate trade and cumulation of materials. The resolution endorsed the legal framework established by the Convention (referenced as 09429/2010) and aligned with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 207 and 218), emphasizing its role in enhancing regional economic integration. It mandated the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its approval to the EU Council, Commission, national governments, parliaments of signatory states, and the Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, ensuring implementation and political alignment among all parties. The decision underscored the strategic importance of standardized rules of origin in reducing trade barriers and fostering cooperation within the Pan-Euro-Med zone.

title: Reinstatement of Myanmar/Burma's access to generalised tariff preferences: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 552/97 temporarily withdrawing access to generalized tariff preferences from Myanmar/Burma
background: Myanmar/Burma lost EU generalized tariff preferences (GSP) in 1997 following ILO-verified systemic forced labor under military rule. Post-2011 political reforms initiated democratization, prompting EU reassessment of trade relations under its GSP framework. The Parliament will discuss reinstating Myanmar/Burma’s tariff preferences amid evolving labor rights and governance conditions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the reinstatement of Myanmar’s GSP access as a strategic tool to reinforce democratic reforms through economic growth, aligning with their commitment to linking trade incentives with governance progress.  
EPP applauds the issue’s recognition of Myanmar’s efforts to eliminate systemic forced labor, matching their emphasis on human rights conditionality in trade agreements.  
EPP endorses the alignment with Aung San Suu Kyi’s explicit request for GSP restoration, reflecting their prioritization of local democratic leadership in EU external policy.  
EPP proposes enhancing post-reinstatement monitoring mechanisms to address ethnic conflicts in Rakhine and Kachin states, ensuring human rights benchmarks remain central to ongoing engagement.  
EPP approves the issue’s adherence to equal treatment principles for developing nations, consistent with their advocacy for non-discriminatory trade frameworks under the Everything But Arms initiative.

GREEN_EFA rejects the premature reinstatement of trade preferences as fundamentally incompatible with their human rights safeguards doctrine.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue’s removal of economic leverage while 130,000 Rohingyas remain systematically oppressed under Burmese authorities.  
This proposal directly contradicts GREEN_EFA’s requirement for verified prisoner releases and ethnic minority protections before trade normalization.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the abandonment of conditionality measures despite unresolved persecution documented by Human Rights Watch and other monitors.  
The issue’s failure to mandate immediate human rights assessments violates GREEN_EFA’s non-negotiable "rights before trade" framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0524) concerning trade-related measures under Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsing the proposal at first reading without amendments. It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending to introduce substantial changes or replace it entirely, ensuring legislative oversight. The resolution further mandated the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence and inter-institutional communication.

title: Repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 on the tariff rates for bananas: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 on the tariff rates for bananas
background: The EU faced prolonged WTO disputes over discriminatory banana tariffs favoring African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) countries, leading to a 2009 Geneva Agreement to reduce most-favored-nation tariffs and establish financial assistance for ACP producers. The Parliament will discuss repealing the 2005 tariff regulation to align with the WTO-brokered settlement.

stances.stance:
SD strongly endorses the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 as a critical step toward fulfilling the EU’s multilateral trade obligations under the Geneva Agreement, aligning with SD’s commitment to equitable global economic integration.  
SD applauds the €190 million Banana Accompanying Measures as essential to safeguarding ACP producers’ livelihoods, directly advancing SD’s priority of protecting vulnerable economies from asymmetric market pressures.  
SD proposes enhancing competition law enforcement mechanisms to prevent multinational monopolistic practices, ensuring the issue’s tariff reductions do not inadvertently harm small-scale producers or consumers.  
SD urges the Commission to formalize the 2020 impact assessment as a binding requirement to evaluate long-term effects on ACP nations and outermost regions, reinforcing transparency in trade policy outcomes.  
SD emphasizes integrating fair trade certification incentives into the agreement’s implementation to elevate labor and environmental standards, reflecting SD’s manifesto goals for ethical consumption.

GUE_NGL firmly doubts the repeal of Regulation 1964/2005 as it sacrifices ACP and EU outermost regions' small producers to multinational corporate interests, directly contradicting their anti-neoliberal trade principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the €190 million compensation package as grossly inadequate to prevent the destruction of traditional banana farming communities, violating their commitment to economic justice.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's alignment with WTO priorities over environmental and worker protections, highlighting its incompatibility with their manifesto's demand for trade policy democratization.  
GUE_NGL denounces the exclusion of ACP producers from negotiations as neo-colonial practice, directly opposing their decolonial trade solidarity principles.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's market liberalization framework incompatible with their vision of food sovereignty, demanding complete rejection rather than technical adjustments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of a resolution endorsing the Agreement on Trade in Bananas, which resolves a longstanding WTO dispute through three key components: a schedule of tariff reductions for most-favoured nation (MFN) banana exporters, a framework for addressing "tropical products" and "preference erosion" in WTO negotiations, and a €190 million financial package (Banana Accompanying Measures) to support ACP banana exporters. The resolution supports abolishing the current EU MFN tariff rate of €176 per tonne for bananas by repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005, aligning with commitments under the Geneva Agreement. It welcomes the conclusion of the WTO dispute as politically and commercially significant, despite not fully reconciling all parties' interests, and affirms that the agreement will finalize EU market access commitments for bananas within the Doha Round agricultural negotiations. The Parliament endorsed the Commission’s proposal at first reading, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments arise, and emphasized integrating the outcomes into broader multilateral trade frameworks.

title: Opening of negotiations on a plurilateral agreement on services: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the opening of negotiations on a plurilateral agreement on services
background: Following stalled WTO Doha Round services negotiations since 2008 and increased post-crisis protectionism, the EU, representing 25.65% of global services exports, proposed plurilateral talks with 21 WTO members to enhance market access. The Parliament will discuss initiating EU participation in services agreement negotiations, balancing economic priorities with regulatory sovereignty and multilateral trade commitments.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the TISA negotiations as entirely disapproveing with their commitment to multilateral trade governance under the WTO framework.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the lack of mandatory sustainability impact assessments, which the issue fails to require before advancing market access commitments.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion of BRICS and African nations from negotiations while maintaining incompatible liberalization demands that perpetuate unequal trade dynamics.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the assertion of WTO compatibility, demanding explicit legal guarantees to prevent corporate challenges to public service regulations.  
GREEN_EFA rejects plurilateral agreements as undermining democratic accountability, citing the Council’s bypassing of parliamentary consultation on the mandate.

SD strongly approves the opening of TISA negotiations, emphasizing services as pivotal to the EU’s economic competitiveness and aligning with SD’s commitment to modernizing trade frameworks beyond outdated GATS commitments.  
SD applauds the issue’s safeguards for public services, cultural sectors, and Mode 4 mobility, reflecting SD’s prioritization of social equity and regulatory sovereignty in trade policy.  
SD endorses the push to include BRICS and ASEAN nations in future negotiations, proposing intensified diplomatic outreach to integrate high-growth markets without diluting liberalization ambitions.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of ongoing parliamentary consultation and transparency, urging the Council to adopt structured stakeholder briefings to enhance democratic oversight.  
SD approves the two-year timeline for concluding TISA, contingent on robust ratchet clauses and procurement rules, vital for locking in long-term economic benefits.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the stagnation of multilateral trade negotiations under the WTO’s Doha Round, emphasizing the critical role of services—constituting 75% of EU GDP and employment, 28% of EU exports in 2011, and 25.65% of global services exports—in sustaining economic competitiveness. It highlighted the outdated and inconsistent nature of GATS commitments, which fail to reflect current trade barriers or autonomous liberalization efforts, and noted the rise of protectionist measures post-2008. The resolution welcomed the EU’s participation in plurilateral Trade in Services Agreement (TISA) negotiations, aiming to advance high-standard liberalization and regulatory disciplines (e.g., transparency, competition, licensing) while preserving the right to regulate public services. It stressed the need for TISA to align with GATS principles, include an accession clause for future multilateralization, and exclude cultural and audiovisual services to protect EU policies. Concerns were raised over the absence of BRICS, ASEAN, and African countries—key growth markets with significant barriers—from negotiations, urging their inclusion without diluting ambition. The Parliament criticized the Council for approving the mandate without prior consultation and demanded ongoing transparency, including a sustainability impact assessment addressing social and environmental impacts. It endorsed a two-year timeline for concluding TISA, contingent on achieving robust market access commitments, standstill/ratchet clauses to lock in liberalization, and addressing procurement and subsidy rules stalled in WTO talks.

title: Protection against dumped and subsidised imports from countries not members of the EU: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Community and Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community
background: The EU's existing trade defense regulations (1225/2009 and 597/2009) faced challenges from evolving global trade practices, increased non-EU subsidized imports, and high-profile cases like Chinese solar panels (2013). The Commission proposed modernization (COM(2013)0192) to address enforcement gaps and WTO compliance. The Parliament will discuss amendments to strengthen protections against dumped and subsidized imports while balancing market openness and EU industry interests.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fully approves the integration of international social and environmental standards into anti-dumping measures, perfectly aligning with their commitment to sustainable and equitable trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s critical role in preventing divisive external pressures like those seen in the Chinese photovoltaic case, ensuring unified EU industrial defense strategies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds enhanced SME access to trade defense mechanisms as a vital step toward balancing global market competitiveness with fair economic participation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the mandate for parliamentary oversight, reinforcing democratic accountability in trade policy as a cornerstone of their governance principles.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the issue’s framework for addressing subsidy-driven market distortions, recognizing its alignment with climate-conscious industrial policy goals.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to prohibit using trade instruments to coerce market access from developing nations, directly conflicting with their 2010 stance on resource sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the omission of binding measures against social/environmental dumping, which the issue overlooks despite UN Charter obligations for equitable cooperation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the regulation’s potential to institutionalize low raw material pricing, perpetuating wage suppression and poverty in violation of decent work principles.  
GUE_NGL disputes the proposal’s compatibility with Article 3 of the UN Charter, as it prioritizes commercial interests over solving economic inequalities through multilateralism.  
GUE_NGL declares the text illegitimate without Amendment 83’s explicit integration of environmental and labor safeguards, rendering it inconsistent with their anti-dumping framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal concerning international trade, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the original proposal (COM(2013)0192) are contemplated, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and institutional alignment in the EU’s trade policy framework.

title: Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EC and Israel on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA): RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the State of Israel, of the other part, on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA)
background: The EU and Israel’s Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement (2000) established trade frameworks, with a 2010-negotiated Protocol on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA) aiming to reduce technical barriers. The EU maintains non-recognition of Israeli jurisdiction in territories occupied since 1967. The Parliament will discuss concluding the CAA Protocol under the existing agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the ACAA protocol as a vital step in eliminating technical trade barriers, aligning with their commitment to deepening Euro-Mediterranean economic cooperation through regulatory alignment.  
EPP applauds the explicit exclusion of products from occupied territories under the protocol’s scope, emphasizing its consistency with EU positions on territorial applicability and Israel’s 1967 borders.  
EPP highlights the agreement’s consumer benefits, particularly accelerated access to high-quality generic pharmaceuticals for EU patients, which aligns with public health priorities and single-market efficiency goals.  
EPP proposes enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure territorial compliance, suggesting regular Commission reporting to maintain transparency without opposing the agreement’s core objectives.  
EPP underscores the importance of maintaining balanced EU-Israel relations, viewing the protocol as a technical instrument that strengthens shared standards while preserving the EU’s role as a neutral mediator in broader regional disputes.

GUE_NGL rejects the protocol as a de facto political endorsement of Israel’s systemic oppression of Palestinians, firmly disputeing with their commitment to anti-colonial solidarity and human rights.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement’s framing as "technical," highlighting its role in integrating Israel into the EU single market despite ongoing illegal settlements and Gaza’s humanitarian crisis.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to address Israel’s blockade of Gaza, which directly contradicts EU principles on freedom of movement and access to essential medicines.  
GUE_NGL asserts that any economic cooperation with Israel legitimizes violations of international law, including the 2012 clarification’s inadequacy to prevent settlement-linked trade normalization.  
GUE_NGL demands unconditional rejection of the protocol, citing Israel’s violent interception of humanitarian aid ships as emblematic of policies incompatible with EU values.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement with Israel on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA), aimed at facilitating trade through mutual recognition of industrial product assessments. It emphasized the need for clarity on the territorial competence of Israeli authorities, following concerns addressed by Commissioner De Gucht’s July 2012 clarification that the protocol’s scope excludes Israeli settlements in occupied territories. The resolution called on the Commission to regularly report on the protocol’s implementation and instructed the Parliament’s President to communicate the decision to relevant EU and Israeli institutions. Key documents referenced include the draft Council decision (12428/2012) and the draft protocol (05212/2010), with committees on International Trade (INTA) and Foreign Affairs (AFET) overseeing procedural alignment under Treaty on the Functioning of the EU Articles 207 and 218.

title: State of play of the Doha development agenda: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda and preparations for the Ninth WTO Ministerial Conference
background: Initiated in 2001 to address trade imbalances and prioritize developing countries, the Doha Development Agenda faced prolonged negotiations, including a 2008 stalemate. With the Ninth WTO Ministerial Conference scheduled for December 2013 in Bali, the EU emphasized multilateral trade and WTO reform. The Parliament will discuss progress on the Doha Round and preparations for the Bali ministerial meeting.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's endorsement of plurilateral agreements like TiSA and GPA as firmly disputeing with their demand for strict multilateral WTO reform, which Franziska Keller explicitly denounced as undermining development priorities.  

GREEN_EFA opposes the proposal to differentiate among developing countries using "objective criteria" as inconsistent with their insistence on full, undiluted special treatment for LDCs in market access and services waiver implementation.  

GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to mandate binding climate obligations in trade rules, overlooking critical aspects of environmental justice central to GREEN_EFA's platform, as highlighted in the debate's emphasis on climate change integration.  

GREEN_EFA rejects the limited ambition on cotton trade reforms and rules of origin adjustments, which the debate identified as non-negotiable for equitable LDC participation in global value chains.  

GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's silence on gender disparity mitigation in trade policy, directly contradicting their principle that trade systems must address structural inequalities as outlined by Keller.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on strengthening parliamentary oversight of WTO decisions, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to democratic legitimacy in global governance through initiatives like the joint EU-Inter-Parliamentary Union conference.  
SD applauds the focus on trade facilitation as a growth catalyst, strongly endorsing binding agreements to streamline customs procedures in line with SD’s advocacy for equitable market access and poverty reduction.  
SD approves the emphasis on concluding the Doha Round’s development pillar, particularly duty-free access for LDCs, which directly advances SD’s priority of addressing systemic trade inequalities through instruments like the Everything but Arms initiative.  
SD proposes strengthening monitoring mechanisms for Aid for Trade commitments to ensure infrastructure funding reaches LDCs as intended, enhancing the issue’s existing call for renewed financial support.  
SD fully sanctions differentiation among developing countries using objective criteria, a position consistent with SD’s long-standing argument against blanket special treatment for advanced economies masquerading as developing nations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for structural reform of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to ensure a fair, open, and rules-based multilateral trading system that prioritizes development, particularly for least developed countries (LDCs) and low-income developing nations. It reaffirmed the Doha Development Agenda’s (DDA) objectives of addressing trade imbalances, fostering sustainable growth, and integrating developing countries into global value chains, while stressing the importance of special and differential treatment (S&DT) tailored to varying economic levels. The resolution highlighted the economic potential of a binding trade facilitation agreement, estimating it could boost global GDP by €68 billion annually through streamlined customs procedures, and urged enhanced Aid for Trade initiatives to counter reduced funding in 2011, particularly for infrastructure and capacity-building. It called for concluding the stalled Doha Round with an ambitious outcome at the 2013 Bali Ministerial Conference, emphasizing duty-free, quota-free access for LDCs (as in the EU’s Everything but Arms initiative) and implementation of the LDC services waiver. The Parliament supported plurilateral agreements like the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and the revised Government Procurement Agreement (GPA), while advocating for technology transfers, renewed negotiations on the Information Technology Agreement, and extended TRIPS exemptions for LDCs until 2021. It stressed addressing non-tariff barriers, promoting environmental goods and services, and ensuring policy coherence between trade, development, and climate goals. The resolution also urged differentiation among developing countries based on objective criteria, greater parliamentary oversight of WTO decisions, and strengthened collaboration with international organizations to align trade with broader socio-economic objectives.

title: Report: Vital Moreira - Macro-financial assistance to Georgia: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision providing macro-financial assistance to Georgia
